item.title: Swipe left: When the government is on Tinder
item.description: The article discusses the implications of the Indian Telecom Bill 2023, which grants the government oversight of all messages transmitted, emitted, or received in any form. This includes wired, electronic, and optical communication. The bill allows for informational monitoring and gives the government the authority to intercept, detain, or choose not to transmit messages from individuals or specific groups. Dating applications like WhatsApp, Instagram, and Telegram collect concrete data points on users' sexuality, political alignment, and preferences. The article raises concerns about the potential misuse of this data by the government and police officials, citing examples from other countries where data from dating apps has been used for surveillance purposes. The article also highlights the impact of laws on public behavior and the lack of accountability mechanisms to prevent abuse or harassment. It questions whether the Telecom Bill will lead to changes in dating profiles and conversations, and how it will affect the privacy and freedom of expression of individuals. Overall, the article raises concerns about the increasing surveillance power of the government and its potential impact on marginalized communities, including queer individuals and sex workers.

item.title: View from Pakistan on civilian deaths in Kashmir and India’s ‘convenient’ counterterrorism alibi
item.description:
Last week, an ambush on two military vehicles in the Poonch district of Jammu and Kashmir resulted in the death of four Indian Army soldiers and the injury of three others [[2]](https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/jammu/4-soldiers-killed-3-wounded-in-poonch-ambush/articleshow/106192020.cms). In the aftermath of the attack, eight civilians were picked up by the army for questioning. Tragically, three of them were found dead later, while the remaining five were admitted to the hospital [[10]](https://tribune.com.pk/story/2451116/indian-army-orders-inquiry-into-alleged-civilian-deaths-in-custody).
The incident has sparked criticism of the Indian Army, particularly in light of the recent upholding of the abrogation of Article 370 by the Supreme Court Dawn, a Pakistani newspaper, laments the lack of justice for the people of Kashmir and accuses the Indian state of using counterterrorism as an excuse to deny the rights of Kashmiris and inflict violence upon them The editorial urges the international community to speak up and hold India accountable for its policies in the region.
The Nation, another Pakistani newspaper, acknowledges the steps taken by the Indian government, such as compensation for the deceased and legal proceedings, as a positive move. However, it emphasizes the need for a comprehensive and impartial investigation to rebuild trust and prevent future atrocities, given the complex history of human rights abuses in Kashmir.
It is important to note that December 25 is celebrated as Christmas and Jinnah Day in Pakistan, a day to remember Muhammad Ali Jinnah, the founder and first governor-general of Pakistan. The media has used this occasion to reflect on Jinnah's values and the vision he had for Pakistan.
News International highlights the connection between Christmas and Jinnah Day, emphasizing the need for tolerance and acceptance of all beliefs in a nation that is divided along religious, sectarian, and ethnic lines. The editorial also acknowledges the challenges faced by minorities in Pakistan, particularly Christians who are often marginalized and denied opportunities for growth.
Daily Times echoes the vision of Jinnah for a country built on the principles of tolerance and equality. It expresses concern about the growing intolerance towards those who express different opinions and emphasizes the importance of treating all citizens with equal rights and dignity.
Moving on to another topic, a recent report by the Asian Development Bank reveals a significant increase in domestic violence against women and children in Pakistan due to the COVID-19 pandemic. Punjab and Sindh have seen a 40% increase in spouses threatening their partners with physical violence and a 46% rise in physical assault [[6]](https://www.rediff.com/news/report/terrorists-ambush-army-vehicles-in-poonch/20231221.htm).
The Express Tribune attributes this rise in domestic violence to the lack of robust social safety nets and challenging conditions at women's rehabilitation and protection centers, which leave women with limited options and compel them to endure abusive situations.
To address this issue, Dawn suggests that education and sensitization programs can play a significant role in changing perceptions and behavior. It also emphasizes the need for corporate policies that support gender equality and provide safe work environments for women. Furthermore, a collective effort from the government, civil society, and the private sector is essential to combat domestic violence, as the cost of inaction is too high.
Shifting focus to Pakistan's debt situation, a report by the United Nations Development Programme (UNDP) analyzes the country's debt situation and suggests measures for responsible financial management, increasing revenue, enforcing fiscal discipline, and diversifying funding sources.
Both The Nation and The Express Tribune discuss two points from the report. First, the need for greater parliamentary oversight for the treasury, and second, the consideration of Pakistan joining the Open Government Partnership to enhance fiscal transparency and empower citizens with insights into government finances.
The Nation emphasizes the importance of encouraging domestic savings, attracting foreign direct investments, and engaging in public-private partnerships for infrastructure development to reduce excessive reliance on external loans and grants The Express Tribune highlights the challenges faced by Pakistan in achieving economic stabilization and sustainable growth, given the current state of the economy and the country's increasing dependence on short-term fixes for economic woes.
In summary, recent events in the Poonch district of Jammu and Kashmir have led to criticism of the Indian Army, while Pakistani newspapers reflect on the values of Muhammad Ali Jinnah and discuss the need for tolerance and equality in the country. Additionally, there has been a concerning increase in domestic violence in Pakistan, and measures are being suggested to address this issue. Finally, the UNDP report provides insights into Pakistan's debt situation and proposes measures for responsible financial management.

item.title: An ode to Akram, spice seller, dietitian, life coach
item.description:
In this article, the author introduces us to a spice seller named Akram at the neighborhood farmers' market. Akram is not just an ordinary spice seller, but he also takes on multiple roles as a nutritionist, dietitian, salesman, life coach, and naturopath. He understands that many shoppers visiting the market have chronic diseases, particularly diabetes, and are looking for alternative ways to manage their conditions.
Akram's stall is filled with a variety of spices, nuts, and seeds, which emit a delightful aroma. He strategically positions himself amidst a pile of winter vegetables to attract customers. Recognizing that most evening shoppers are women, he capitalizes on their family's health consciousness to promote his products. He even uses English names for the spices because he knows that many customers are active on social media platforms like Instagram and TikTok.
Most women who visit Akram's stall are interested in buying spices because he hand-pounds them, ensuring authentic taste and food value. He offers different pouch sizes, asking customers whether they want 100 grams or 200 grams. He explains that packaged spices available in stores may be stale since they often sit in warehouses for months.
To convince hesitant customers, Akram appeals to their specific needs. He suggests sunflower seeds for skin health and grape seeds for hair health. If customers remain unconvinced, he emphasizes the convenience of incorporating his products into their daily routines. For example, he recommends sprinkling sunflower seeds on salads or cereal, or keeping them as a snack in the side pocket of a laptop bag. If all else fails, he highlights the blood sugar-lowering properties of his products, referring to fasting blood sugar levels as "khaali pet ka blood sugar."
Interestingly, studies have shown that sunflower seeds containing high levels of chlorogenic acid can indeed lower fasting blood sugar levels. Other studies have also found that people who consume seeds at least five times a week have lower levels of C-reactive protein, an indicator of heart health. Akram understands that women may be sensitive about weight issues, so he also suggests pumpkin seeds and chia seeds as they are beneficial for blood pressure and weight reduction.
If blood pressure is not a concern, Akram switches to other benefits to cater to his customers' preferences. He highlights the sleep-promoting properties of chia seeds, which are rich in melatonin, the sleep hormone. He also promotes flax seeds for their benefits in improving digestion and gut health. Additionally, Akram emphasizes the detoxifying virtues of Himalayan pink salt, presenting it as a more natural alternative to table salt.
The author commends Akram for keeping himself well-informed in the digital age and for understanding what women of all ages want. He effectively communicates with them using language that resonates with their desires. For those who prefer a more traditional approach, Akram also offers home-made turmeric and chili powder, along with 50 grams of any seed for free. He concludes by stating that Akram's expertise lies in his ability to cater to his customers' needs and speak their language, all while injecting doses of humor and sharing his borrowed knowledge.

item.title: Tavleen Singh writes: PM Modi’s guarantees vs Rahul Gandhi’s promises
item.description:
#### Summary of "Tavleen Singh's Last Column of 2023"
Tavleen Singh's last column of 2023 reflects on the significant political changes in India over the past year. The column focuses on the rise of Narendra Modi as the central figure in the BJP, the impact of his leadership on the party, and the challenges faced by the opposition, particularly the Congress Party led by Rahul Gandhi. Singh highlights Modi's strong influence on voters, his successful implementation of promises such as the construction of the Ram Temple in Ayodhya, and the perceived strength and respect of India on the global stage under Modi's leadership. The column also discusses the ideological differences between Modi and Gandhi, the challenges faced by the opposition alliance, and the lack of a unified ideology among its members.
#### Narendra Modi's Political Influence Singh emphasizes the significant political change in India, where Narendra Modi has emerged as the dominant figure within the BJP, overshadowing other party leaders and the RSS. She notes that voters now primarily associate their support with Modi rather than the BJP as a whole.
#### Modi's Promises and Achievements The article highlights Modi's personal guarantees to voters, particularly regarding the construction of the Ram Temple in Ayodhya, which has garnered significant attention and support. The author also mentions the perceived positive impact of Modi's leadership on India's global standing, citing the G20 annual meeting and the abrogation of Article 370 as examples that have resonated with voters.
#### Rahul Gandhi and the Opposition Singh discusses Rahul Gandhi's ideological stance and the challenges faced by the Congress Party in countering Modi's influence. She questions the effectiveness of Gandhi's ideology in appealing to the average voter and contrasts it with Modi's more resonant promises and leadership style.
#### Challenges Faced by the Opposition Alliance The article highlights the lack of a unified ideology among the parties in the opposition alliance and their struggle to present a cohesive alternative to Modi's leadership. Singh also mentions the alliance's difficulty in convincing voters of the urgency to remove Modi from power and the perceived weakness of their responses to Modi's guarantees.
In summary, Tavleen Singh's column provides insights into the evolving political landscape in India, focusing on the dominance of Narendra Modi, the challenges faced by the opposition, and the contrasting leadership styles and ideologies of Modi and Rahul Gandhi.

item.title: Shutting out debate in talking shop
item.description:
#### Summary:
The article discusses the importance of Parliament as a "talking shop" and the need for debate and discussion in the legislative process. It highlights the recent Winter Session of Parliament in India, where important legislation was passed but without meaningful debate. The article also focuses on a security breach that occurred during the session and criticizes the government's response to it. It expresses concern about the disintegration of the Winter Session and the potential irrelevance of Parliament in the governance of the country. The author concludes with a message of hope for the future of Parliament.
#### Importance of Debate in Parliament:
The article argues that Parliament should remain a "talking shop" and emphasizes the significance of debate in the legislative process. It states that passing legislation without debate raises suspicions about its legitimacy.
#### Winter Session of Parliament:
The Winter Session of Parliament in India began on December 4, 2023, and was scheduled to end on December 21. The government had a substantial agenda, including the passage of important legislation, while the Opposition presented a long list of issues for debate. The session started peacefully in both Houses, and business was transacted for more than a week.
#### Security Breach and Government's Response:
During the Winter Session, a serious security breach occurred when two individuals jumped from the Visitors' gallery in the Lok Sabha and released colored-gas canisters. The MPs overpowered the intruders, but it was considered a grave breach of security. It was later revealed that the two individuals had been recommended for passes by a BJP MP from Karnataka. The Opposition demanded a statement from the Home Minister regarding the violation, but the government refused to make a statement, leading to uproar and continuous disruption.
#### Disintegration of the Winter Session:
The article criticizes the government for not making a statement on the security breach and refusing to discuss the matter in Parliament. It highlights precedents where the government made statements and held discussions in similar situations. The disintegration of the Winter Session was of no concern to the government, which resulted in the suspension of 146 MPs belonging to both Houses. Despite the disruptions, several bills were passed without meaningful debate.
#### Concerns about the Governance of the Country:
The author expresses concern that a disrupted and non-functional Parliament is of no consequence to the governance of the country. There is a fear that India's Parliament may become irrelevant and obediently endorse the actions of the Executive. The disintegration of the Winter Session has deepened these suspicions and fears.
#### Conclusion:
The article concludes with a message of hope for the future of Parliament and wishes the readers a Happy New Year.
**Note:** The summary provided is based on the information available in the article.

item.title: Coomi Kapoor writes: Losers list 2023 — three institutions come to mind
item.description:
#### Summary of "Year-end Reflection: The Losers of 2023"
The article reflects on the year 2023, highlighting the underperformance of three key institutions: Parliament, the Opposition, and the mainstream media.
**Parliament** - The new parliament building's architecture is criticized for creating a divide between MPs and the people they represent. Inside the building, an unprecedented 146 MPs were suspended during the winter session, and 17 Bills were passed at lightning speed, including far-reaching amendments to Colonial-era civil and criminal codes. The ruling party measures parliamentary performance in terms of the speed with which Bills are passed, ignoring the importance of discussion, debate, and consensus-building between the ruling party and the Opposition. The Home Minister's refusal to speak on a security breach in Parliament during a session demonstrated a refusal to accept the principle of accountability.
**Opposition** - The Opposition is criticized for its failure to present an inspiring alternative to the ruling party. The inability to project a charismatic face to counter Narendra Modi's mass appeal is highlighted. The article also mentions the lack of consensus on seat-sharing or projecting a common prime ministerial candidate within the Opposition. It points out the lack of hunger for power, determination, and commitment compared to the ruling party's election machine.
**Media** - The mainstream media is criticized for losing its impartiality due to constricted budgets, conditioned advertising, and legal impediments. The article highlights the emergence of a new category of "influencer" scribes challenging the role of conventional journalism. It notes that some influencers have been successful in attracting followers through easy-to-relate imagery and slick presentations, while traditional media is failing to reinvent itself.
Overall, the article emphasizes the negative impact of these underperforming institutions on the country's democratic processes and public discourse.
#### Conclusion The article provides a critical reflection on the underperformance of Parliament, the Opposition, and the mainstream media in 2023, highlighting the implications for the country's democratic processes and public discourse.

item.title: Beginning of the end: Triumph in ULFA Peace Accord marks a national security milestone
item.description:
The article discusses the complex and protracted process of engaging in dialogue with belligerent groups, particularly in the Indian context. It highlights the Naga Peace Process as the longest-running in the world, marred by mistakes and interference. The approach in India’s northeast has often been neglect or attempts to "wear out" insurgent groups, but a positive development occurred on December 29 with the successful conclusion of dialogue with the ULFA (Pro-Talks).
The article provides a historical background of the ULFA, a militant group formed in Assam in 1979, which wielded significant influence during its peak. It operated in urban settings and had bases in neighboring countries, allowing for strategic encirclement of the Northeast. However, active military operations, including armed intervention by Bhutan, led to the group losing control. Subsequently, the return of the Awami League government in Bangladesh facilitated the handover of ULFA leaders to India, paving the way for peace talks.
The peace agreement, while seen as a significant national security success, has faced criticism due to the continued absence of the Paresh Baruah faction from the dialogue process. There are also concerns about attempts by ULFA (Independent) to make a comeback. The recent apprehension of a ULFA member in Arunachal Pradesh has dealt a blow to the organization’s efforts to regain lost ground, and it is widely acknowledged that the group led by Paresh Baruah is in decline.
Overall, the article underscores the significance of the December 29, 2023 achievement by New Delhi in dealing with the ULFA, while acknowledging the ongoing challenges and complexities involved in peace processes with belligerent groups in the region.

item.title: From Princesestan to Article 370: how India evaded Balkanisation
item.description:
On the eve of Independence, Jawaharlal Nehru delivered his “Tryst with Destiny” speech, which is considered one of the greatest speeches of the 20th century. In the speech, Nehru spoke about the tryst that India had made with destiny and the time to redeem that pledge. He acknowledged that while the pledge may not be fully realized, it would be substantially fulfilled [[1]].
In the run-up to independence, a plan was devised by a few powerful princes to create a third dominion called Princesestan, along with India and Pakistan. This plan aimed to keep the 565 princely states outside the control of the two free states and retain paramountcy under the departing British. However, Jawaharlal Nehru, Sardar Patel, and Lord Mountbatten opposed this plan and successfully foiled the British attempt to balkanize India [[2]].
At the 1929 Lahore session of the Indian National Congress, the Purna Swaraj declaration, also known as the "Declaration of the Independence of India," was promulgated. This declaration declared January 26, 1930, as Independence Day and called on people to pledge themselves to civil disobedience until India achieved complete independence. From 1930 to 1946, the Indian National Congress observed January 26 as Independence Day, marked by meetings where attendees took the pledge of independence [[3]].
The Indian Independence Act 1947, passed by the Parliament of the United Kingdom, partitioned British India into the two new independent dominions of India and Pakistan. The Act granted complete legislative authority to the respective constituent assemblies of the new countries and came into effect on August 15, 1947 [[4]].
Following independence, millions of Muslim, Sikh, and Hindu refugees crossed the newly drawn borders, resulting in widespread violence and bloodshed. Between 250,000 and 1,000,000 people on both sides of the new borders lost their lives in the violence. While the nation celebrated Independence Day, Mahatma Gandhi stayed in Calcutta to try to stem the carnage [[5]].
The article also mentions the recent decision by the BJP government to make Article 370 inoperable, repeal Article 35A, and bifurcate the state of Jammu and Kashmir into two union territories. This decision was seen as a significant moment in Kashmir's history and was expected to draw reactions from Kashmiris and the international community [[6]].
Overall, the article discusses the historical events leading up to India's independence, including Nehru's famous speech, the opposition to the plan for a third dominion, the observance of Independence Day by the Indian National Congress, the partition of British India, and the violence that followed. It also touches on the recent decision regarding Article 370 and the integration of Jammu and Kashmir with India [[1]] [[2]] [[3]] [[4]] [[5]] [[6]].

item.title: Unhinged in 2023: In a year of global chaos, dark humour is a sign we are still human
item.description:
#### Summary of the Article: The article reflects on the author's personal experiences and observations of the year 2023, describing it as "unhinged." The author discusses various global events that occurred throughout the year, including political changes, natural disasters, and social unrest. They also delve into the concept of being "unhinged" in the context of modern existence, particularly in online subcultures like TikTok and Instagram Reels. The author connects this concept to their studies in Political Philosophy, highlighting the fine line between utopias and dystopias and the role of human agency in shaping these societal constructs. Ultimately, the author expresses a sense of solidarity with others who feel "unhinged" and sees it as a demonstration of agency in the face of overwhelming realities and impending dystopias.
#### Notable Events in 2023: - **January:** Jacinda Ardern resigns as New Zealand’s Prime Minister. - **February:** One year of the Russia-Ukraine war and earthquakes in Turkey and Syria. - **March:** Xi Jinping reelected for the third time in China, and union strikes turn violent in France. - **April:** India becomes the world’s most populous country. - **May:** World Health Organisation declares Covid over, and King Charles III is crowned as the 40th British monarch. - **June:** Protests in France over the shooting of young Nahel Merzouk. - **July:** Hottest month in human history. - **August:** Donald Trump is arrested and spends 20 minutes in jail. - **September:** India shines in G20, but India-Canada relations deteriorate over a pro-Khalistan separatist leader’s killing. - **October:** Violence in Gaza begins. - **November:** CEO of OpenAI is removed and then rehired. - **December:** Escalation of conflicts in Gaza and Ukraine-Russia.
#### Reflection on "Unhinged" Culture: The author explores the concept of being "unhinged" in the context of modern existence, particularly in online subcultures like TikTok and Instagram Reels. They note the prevalence of indifference and dark humor as recurring themes, with young people rationalizing problematic situations as necessary conditions for their "character arcs." The author sees this as a coping mechanism for the visceral violence that has become a part of modern existence.
#### Connection to Political Philosophy: The author, who studies Political Philosophy, reflects on the distinction between utopias and dystopias, highlighting the fine line between the two and the role of human agency in shaping societal constructs. They express a sense of solidarity with others who feel "unhinged" and see it as a demonstration of agency in the face of overwhelming realities and impending dystopias.
#### Conclusion: The author concludes by expressing hope that the chaos experienced in 2023 can be translated into action in 2024, allowing them to address the never-ending list of things they would like to fix. They see being "unhinged" in 2023 as proof that, in the face of evil, individuals are not immune, at least not yet.
This summary is based on the information provided in the article.

item.title: Decoding Bangladesh election: Sheikh Hasina’s manifesto, economic challenges, and the crucial West factor
item.description: The article discusses the election manifesto presented by Bangladesh Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina and the current political and economic situation in the country. The manifesto focuses on creating jobs, social security, and good governance to build a "Smart Bangladesh" by 2041. Sheikh Hasina's tenure has seen significant social and economic accomplishments, including rapid economic growth and a reduction in extreme poverty. She has also dealt with Islamic militancy and maintained a balance between the interests of major global powers. However, the economy has faced challenges in the last two years, including macroeconomic stress and mismanagement of the financial sector. This has led to a decline in foreign reserves and high inflation. A survey indicates that a majority of Bangladeshis feel the country is headed in the wrong direction, despite Sheikh Hasina's high personal approval rating. The article also discusses the political dynamics between the Awami League (AL) and the Bangladesh Nationalist Party (BNP), with the BNP demanding the resignation of the prime minister and the reinstatement of an interim government for the upcoming national election. The article highlights the historic political animosity between the two parties and the potential impact of Western interest in the election process. The US has expressed a desire for a free, fair, and peaceful national election in Bangladesh, which some speculate is motivated by a desire to halt democratic regression or to counter China's influence in the region. The article concludes by stating that the upcoming election is unlikely to heal the deeply divided political arena and emphasizes the need for compromise and consensus among political stakeholders for a stronger democratic fabric in Bangladesh.

item.title: Ram Madhav writes on navigating AI: Insights from PM Modi, Pope Francis
item.description:
Prime Minister Narendra Modi recently inaugurated the Global Partnership on Artificial Intelligence (GPAI) Summit in Delhi, where he emphasized India's potential to become a hub for the AI ecosystem. While acknowledging the positive aspects of AI, Modi also highlighted the serious challenges associated with the technology, such as deep fakes, cyber security, data theft, and the potential for terrorists to access AI tools.
The article discusses how AI is revolutionizing the world, with advancements in machine learning and the development of AI-driven programs like Google's Alpha Zero. The author raises concerns about the increasing intelligence of machines and the potential for them to surpass humans, causing anxiety among many individuals, including prominent figures like Elon Musk [[1]](https://theunn.com/category/technology/).
The article also mentions the efforts of various leaders and organizations to address the ethical implications of AI. The Vatican hosted a dialogue on AI ethics, resulting in the "Rome Call for AI Ethics," which emphasized the need for digital innovation to serve human values and not replace them [[1]](https://theunn.com/category/technology/). The Delhi Declaration, released at the G-20 Summit, called for a "Responsible Human-Centric AI" and the creation of a global framework for the ethical use of AI.
The Pope, in his New Year message titled "Artificial Intelligence and Peace," expressed concern about the implications of digital advancements on justice, harmony, and international stability. He emphasized the importance of preserving fundamental human values in the face of AI [[1]](https://theunn.com/category/technology/).
The article concludes by highlighting the need for ethical interventions and philosophical frameworks to guide the development and use of AI. It references Henry Kissinger's book, "The Age of AI: And Our Human Future," which emphasizes the lack of contemplation on the implications of AI for humanity [[1]](https://theunn.com/category/technology/).
Overall, the article underscores the importance of addressing the ethical challenges posed by AI and calls for a thoughtful and responsible approach to its development and use

item.title: COP28’s failure to frame binding commitments raises questions
item.description:
The article discusses the outcomes and challenges of the COP28 conference in Dubai. India, despite not signing any pledges, endorsed two declarations of intent related to low-carbon hydrogen and finance accessibility. However, the reluctance of countries to frame these pledges as binding agreements undermines their effectiveness. The article questions the impact of COP conferences on countries' actions and raises concerns about the efficacy of the annual event.
The UN predicts a temperature increase between 2.5 and 2.9 degrees Celsius, even if this year's pledges are implemented. The world is still projected to exceed the 1.5 degrees Celsius target set at COP21 in Paris. The article highlights the per capita emissions of countries since the Rio Earth Summit in 1992. The average American emitted nearly 700 tonnes of greenhouse gases (GHG) between 1992 and 2019, surpassing the global average by over threefold. The US needs to exceed its current emission reduction commitments to meet climate goals. Similarly, China's emissions align with the global average, but its construction of coal-fired power stations necessitates improvements in its pledge to reach peak emissions by 2030.
The G20 countries collectively contributed 74% of global emissions in 2021. While some countries like the EU, Japan, Canada, South Korea, and the UK are reducing pollution, Russia lacks significant emission-cutting initiatives despite its 4.4% share of emissions. India, Brazil, Indonesia, and African countries face unique challenges in cutting fossil fuel usage due to their relatively modest historical contributions to global warming. The article suggests that powerful countries should set ambitious targets and influence others to follow suit for a more effective strategy.
The article also highlights India's energy pathways, emphasizing the persistence of coal investments despite advancements in renewable energy deployment. Coal constitutes approximately 45% of India's energy supply and 70% of electricity production. The transition away from coal must be well-planned to avoid tremendous human, economic, and social costs. The economic viability of coal is diminishing as the cost of renewables plus storage is now lower than new coal capacity. The focus should shift to upgrading the grid, overcoming financial challenges faced by loss-making discoms, and implementing regulatory mechanisms for solar mini-grids.
Despite criticism of India's coal stance, the final COP28 text considers natural gas as a necessary bridge fuel. However, methane, the primary component of natural gas, contributes nearly 45% of current warming. Addressing methane emissions is crucial for swift progress against climate change. India can tackle anthropogenic sources of methane through technology and improved water management.
India has played a significant role in shaping the discourse on equity, climate justice, and energy access. It has reduced emission intensity by 33% and surpassed its 2030 target ahead of schedule. However, challenges persist in aligning policy with sustainable development. The article concludes by emphasizing the importance of robust commitments from leaders worldwide to avert a climate disaster.
Please note that the information provided is a summary of the article and does not reflect my own opinion or endorsement.

item.title: The Bollywood male in 2023: A year-end reflection
item.description:
#### Summary of the Article "Masculinity in Bollywood: A Year-End Roundtable Conversation"
The article discusses the diverse depictions of masculinity in Bollywood films in 2023 and the contrasting portrayals of male characters. It highlights the emergence of unconventional male characters and the exploration of various shades of masculinity in contrast to traditional "alpha male" stereotypes.
The article begins by describing a scene from the movie "12th Fail," where the protagonist, Manoj, idolizes a police officer, showcasing a rare depiction of a man idolizing another man in Hindi cinema. It contrasts this with the hyper-masculine portrayals in other films, such as Shah Rukh Khan's roles in "Pathaan" and "Jawan," and Ranveer Singh's character in "Rocky Aur Rani Kii Prem Kahaani."
The author also mentions the film "Joram," which features a tribal man, Dasru, portrayed by Manoj Bajpayee, who defies conventional masculinity and is governed by survival instincts. Additionally, the article discusses the film "Animal" and the response it elicited regarding the portrayal of masculinity in Bollywood.
Furthermore, the article highlights films like "Three Of Us" and "Satyaprem Ki Katha," which depict men in more supportive, gentle, and emotionally available roles, challenging traditional gender norms. It also emphasizes the evolving portrayal of masculinity in Bollywood, where characters like Manoj Sharma in "12th Fail" are not depicted with conventional machismo but are celebrated for their dedication and strive for a better life.
The article concludes by suggesting that Bollywood seems to be engaged in a year-end roundtable conversation with itself, exploring the extent to which different depictions of masculinity can be embraced, and speculates on the potential deadlock in deciding the direction for future portrayals of male characters in Bollywood.
Overall, the article provides a comprehensive overview of the evolving representations of masculinity in Bollywood films in 2023, highlighting the diversity and complexity of male characters portrayed on screen.

item.title: Express View on the PM-Kisan model: Not the way forward
item.description:
The Narendra Modi government is implementing a "saturation drive" to increase the number of farmer-beneficiaries under the Pradhan Mantri Kisan Samman Nidhi (PM-Kisan) scheme from around 8.12 crore to approximately 8.75 crore. The PM-Kisan scheme is a direct income support program that provides eligible landowning farmers with a flat payment of Rs 6,000 per year in three equal installments, regardless of the crops they grow or the prices at which they sell them. This subsidy is not biased towards any specific type of farming, whether chemical-based or natural farming. The government is considering refinements to the scheme, such as providing the income support on a per-acre basis up to a certain limit, to address concerns about the benefits received by rich farmers compared to smallholders. The funds for this change could come from ending market-distorting subsidies on farm inputs and outputs, such as fertilizers and government grain procurement at high support prices. By redirecting these savings, the government can ensure that money is not a constraint for implementing per-acre payments under the PM-Kisan scheme and state government-financed direct income support schemes. The challenge lies in the political will to make these changes [[1]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pradhan_Mantri_Kisan_Samman_Nidhi).
The PM-Kisan scheme was launched by the Indian government on December 1, 2018, and provides an income support of Rs 6,000 per year to all eligible farmer families across the country in three equal installments of Rs 2,000 each every four months. The responsibility of identifying beneficiary farmer families rests with the state and union territory governments, and the funds are directly transferred to the beneficiaries' bank accounts. The scheme covers husband, wife, and minor children as the definition of a family. Farmers who fall under the exclusion criteria mentioned in the operational guidelines are not eligible for the scheme. To enroll in the scheme, farmers need to approach the local patwari, revenue officer, or the Nodal Officer (PM-Kisan) nominated by the state government [[5]](https://ladakh.nic.in/scheme/pradhan-mantri-kisan-samman-nidhi-pm-kisan/).
The PM-Kisan scheme can be compared to other similar schemes such as the Rythu Bandhu scheme in Telangana, which provides farmers with up to Rs 12,000 per acre per year. The Rythu Bandhu scheme has faced criticism for allegedly benefiting rich farmers over smallholders. However, it is argued that farmers with larger holdings or those growing more crops have higher expenditures and may be more dependent on income from agriculture. Therefore, providing extra support to such farmers can be justified. Implementing per-acre payments up to a certain limit under the PM-Kisan scheme can address concerns about the benefits received by different categories of farmers [[1]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pradhan_Mantri_Kisan_Samman_Nidhi).
In terms of funding, one suggestion is to redirect the savings from ending market-distorting subsidies on farm inputs and outputs towards the PM-Kisan scheme and state government-financed direct income support schemes. For example, the fertiliser subsidy alone is budgeted at Rs 1,75,100 crore. If this amount were distributed among the projected 8.75 crore PM-Kisan beneficiaries, it would work out to over Rs 20,000 per farmer. By considering similar savings from inefficient and environmentally-disastrous subsidies by states, the necessary funds can be made available for per-acre payments under the PM-Kisan scheme.
In conclusion, the Narendra Modi government is working to increase the number of farmer-beneficiaries under the PM-Kisan scheme. While the scheme's flat income support of Rs 6,000 per year to all eligible farmers is commendable, refinements such as per-acre payments up to a certain limit can address concerns about the benefits received by different categories of farmers. The funds for implementing per-acre payments can be obtained by redirecting savings from ending market-distorting subsidies on farm inputs and outputs. This would require political will and commitment from the government [[1]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pradhan_Mantri_Kisan_Samman_Nidhi)

item.title: Express View on AI in the new year: First, don’t panic
item.description:
The article discusses the public conversation around technology governance, particularly in relation to AI. It highlights the launch of the Large Language Model (LLM) ChatGPT by OpenAI in November 2022, which has disrupted the technology space and led to the democratization of LLMs. The article also mentions the race between major companies and countries, such as Google, China, and the US, to develop Artificial General Intelligence (AGI). This development has raised questions about the regulation of AI.
The article points out a curious dichotomy between the advantages and dangers of AI. The advantages include advanced gene sequencing, tutoring for students, writing code, and virtual assistants. On the other hand, the dangers are often portrayed in apocalyptic terms, with concerns about the impact of LLMs and AI on creativity, work, the economy, and society as a whole. The article suggests two possible reasons for this dichotomy. First, developers may have a fair idea of AI's capabilities but may be less aware of its impacts. Second, the jobs threatened by LLMs and possible AGIs are white-collar jobs based on intellectual and cognitive abilities, which differ from earlier disruptions that primarily affected manufacturing jobs.
The article warns against the panic surrounding AI, as it could lead to stifling regulations that limit the potential benefits of AI. It also highlights the need to address concerns related to plagiarism, authorship, copyright, and the use of AI for surveillance and predictive policing. The article emphasizes that addressing these concerns requires expertise beyond that of engineers and technologists. It suggests that in 2024, society should drive technology rather than the other way around.
Overall, the article discusses the disruptive impact of AI, the dichotomy between its advantages and dangers, and the need for thoughtful regulation and societal involvement in shaping technology governance.

item.title: If Jammu and Kashmir has done well since Article 370 was abrogated, why has statehood not been restored?
item.description:
The article titled "If Jammu and Kashmir has prospered since the abrogation, why has statehood not been restored?" discusses the situation in Jammu and Kashmir after the abrogation of Article 370 in August 2019. The author, a cardiologist named Upendra Kaul, reflects on the promises of development and prosperity made by the government but highlights the lack of progress in attracting investors, creating jobs, and improving the lives of the people in the region [[1]](https://indianexpress.com/article/opinion/columns/jammu-and-kashmir-prospered-abrogation-article-370-statehood-9087784/).
The article begins by mentioning the positive conditions that existed in Jammu and Kashmir before the abrogation of Article 370. The people were content with the leadership of Sheikh Mohammad Abdullah and Jawaharlal Nehru, and the special status enjoyed by J&K under Article 370 helped maintain their relationship with their identity.
However, the author points out that the situation started to deteriorate after Sheikh Abdullah was dismissed in 1953 and replaced by Bakshi Ghulam Mohammad as the Prime Minister of Jammu and Kashmir. The author also highlights the rigged elections in 1987, which led to a violent period in the Valley, including the killings of Kashmiri Pandits and Muslims who supported India. This resulted in the mass migration of Kashmiri Pandits in 1990 [[1]](https://indianexpress.com/article/opinion/columns/jammu-and-kashmir-prospered-abrogation-article-370-statehood-9087784/).
The author mentions that they were unable to return to the Valley until 1997 when things started improving under Governor K V Krishna Rao. However, protests, stone pelting, and separatist movements continued, with the All Parties Hurriyat Conference being formed under the leadership of Syed Ali Shah Geelani. The author also notes the changing governments at the Centre, including the Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) coming to power under Atal Bihari Vajpayee and later Narendra Modi.
The abrogation of Article 370 in August 2019 is described as a long-awaited agenda of the Rashtriya Swayamsevak Sangh (RSS) fulfilled by the Modi government. The author acknowledges some positive steps taken by the government, such as showcasing the return of peace to European delegates and hosting part of India's G20 meet in the Valley. However, the author argues that these steps were premature as militancy was still prevalent.
The article also mentions the challenges faced by the people of Jammu and Kashmir, including inadequate electricity supply, poor road conditions, and sanitation issues. The Freedom House organization rated Jammu and Kashmir's conditions as "Not Free" in 2023, with low scores for political rights and civil liberties [[1]](https://indianexpress.com/article/opinion/columns/jammu-and-kashmir-prospered-abrogation-article-370-statehood-9087784/).
The author concludes by questioning why Jammu and Kashmir's statehood has not been restored and why there are no signs of an election four years after the abrogation of Article 370. The author suggests that despite some positive developments, the promises of development and prosperity have not been fully realized, leaving educated youth with few suitable job opportunities and parents reluctant to let their children leave Kashmir for fear of harm.
Overall, the article highlights the challenges and unfulfilled promises in Jammu and Kashmir since the abrogation of Article 370, raising questions about the progress made in the region.

item.title: Israel’s 2023: Triumphs and tragedies — navigating democracy, security, and the paradox of military strength
item.description:
The year 2023 was a significant year for Israel, characterized by two major events that had a lasting impact on the country. The first event was a 10-month-long democratic movement that aimed to defend an independent judiciary against the government led by Benjamin Netanyahu. This movement, which challenged Netanyahu's long hold on power, revitalized Israel's civil society through a grassroots approach.
The second event was a terror attack by Hamas on October 7. The attack resulted in the deaths of over 1,200 people in less than 24 hours, with more than 240 individuals taken hostage. Many of the hostages are reportedly still captive in Gaza. The attack affected not only major cities but also villages and small communities like Kibbutzim. As a result, more than 100,000 people remain displaced.
Prior to 2023, Israel had experienced political instability, with short-lived coalitions and four national elections in less than two years. Netanyahu, a divisive figure, had been part of multiple governments between 2020 and 2022. He eventually formed a coalition consisting of ultra-nationalist and religious parties. This coalition sought to restructure the balance of power between the judiciary and the executive, which was met with resistance. Many people perceived these aggressive judicial reforms as an attack on the liberal-secular foundations of the state. In response, nationwide strikes and mass protests were organized. Netanyahu's firing of his defense minister, Yoav Gallant, for speaking against the government's agenda further fueled the protests and led to a national shutdown, including the closure of the international airport on March 27.
Throughout the year, there was a sense of purpose and energy among the people of Israel. Individuals from all walks of life took to the streets to demonstrate the power of the people in a democratic, non-violent, and creative struggle for democracy. However, the brutal and unprecedented attack by Hamas overshadowed this movement. The multi-pronged attack caught the state, army, intelligence services, and the people off guard. It occurred during a week of religious observance and involved thousands of infiltrators flooding the south, while the entire country faced heavy rocket fire from Gaza. It took the army five days to fight the terrorists within Israeli towns and Kibbutzim.
Following the attack, the Israeli army and political leaders declared a full-scale war on Gaza with the aim of "wiping out" Hamas. However, after three months of war, Hamas remains intact, and the Israeli people are left with a conflict that shows no signs of resolution. The war has resulted in over 20,000 civilian deaths in Gaza and the displacement of more than a million people, who now live in tents.
As a result of these events, Israelis find themselves disillusioned and uncertain about the future. They are faced with a seemingly endless war and leaders they no longer trust. This has also led to a questioning of the narrative of military security, which has been emphasized in Israel and other nations. The reliance on leaders like Benjamin Netanyahu for conflict management, rather than seeking a resolution with the Palestinians, is being challenged.
In conclusion, the year 2023 was a pivotal year for Israel, marked by a democratic movement to defend the judiciary and a devastating terror attack by Hamas. These events have left a lasting impact on the country, with political instability, displacement, and disillusionment among the people. The need for a resolution to the conflict and a reevaluation of military security narratives has become apparent

item.title: The flipside of ‘Nari Shakti’ — Mahua Moitra, Mayawati and the boys’ club of Indian politics
item.description:
The article discusses the issue of gender inequality and the male-dominated nature of politics in India. It highlights the lack of representation of women in Parliament and state assemblies, as well as the challenges faced by women politicians, including online harassment and attacks on their personal lives. The article also mentions the Nari Shakti Vandan Adhiniyam, a law that reserves 33% of seats in Parliament and state assemblies for women, but questions whether Indian politics is ready for such a change. The author emphasizes the need to understand and address the reality of women's experiences in order to maximize the benefits of women's reservation. The article concludes by quoting statements from women politicians who advocate for standing up against bullies and fighting for equality.
**Key Points:** - India ranks 148th out of 193 countries in terms of women's representation in Parliament, with only 15% of seats held by women. - Women in Indian politics, especially from multilingual areas and marginalized castes, are targeted the most by online trolls. - The socio-political atmosphere in India is shaped by the male standpoint, which reinforces traditional gender roles and expectations for women politicians. - The Nari Shakti Vandan Adhiniyam reserves 33% of seats in Parliament and state assemblies for women, but its implementation may take time. - Women politicians face challenges such as attacks on their character and personal lives, as well as a lack of privacy. - The article suggests that to maximize the benefits of women's reservation, the reality of women's experiences should be acknowledged and addressed.

item.title: With strong role models to look up to, women across the desi heartland can say, ‘Yes we can’
item.description:
The article discusses the passing of the Nari Shakti Vandan Adhiniyam, a legislation that reserves one-third of the seats in the Lok Sabha and state assemblies for women. This move is seen as a significant step towards inclusive governance and empowering women in policy and law-making [[1]](https://wcd.nic.in/sites/default/files/ar-2-211E_merged.pdf).
The article highlights the importance of having powerful female role models in various fields, such as politics, industry, and sports. It mentions President Droupadi Murmu, the first head of state from a tribal community, and Finance Minister Nirmala Sitharaman, the first woman to present five consecutive budgets. These women serve as inspiration for young girls and women, showing them that they too can achieve great things.
The article also discusses the increasing representation of women in managerial positions, both in rural and urban areas. The Periodic Labour Force Survey data shows that female representation in legislative, senior bureaucratic, and managerial roles in villages is higher than in urban areas. This trend is attributed to the growing number of female-led start-ups and increased access to resources through digital platforms.
The article emphasizes the importance of positive female role models in public life, as they encourage other women and help balance the male-female dynamics. It mentions the impact of role models like Kiran Bedi, the first woman to join the police services, and Smriti Irani, the Union Minister for Women and Child Development, who challenges stereotypes and inspires others through her determination and hard work.
Furthermore, the article acknowledges the positive change in the portrayal of women in films and series, where women characters are depicted as strong and independent. This shift in cultural representation reflects the growing social acceptance of women in their full humanity, as heroes, villains, and everything in between.
In conclusion, the article highlights the importance of female role models in driving positive change and empowering women. It emphasizes the ongoing revolution where barriers are being broken down, and women are rewriting their stories and shattering the glass ceiling

item.title: December 29, 1983, Forty Years Ago: PM calls for unity
item.description:

The article discusses various topics, including the need to safeguard the unity of the country, Sunil Gavaskar's record-breaking Test century, the reorganization of India's foreign office, the release of Indian prisoners from Pakistani jails, and Indian science reaching the Moon in 2023.

Sunil Gavaskar scored his 30th Test century at Chepauk, surpassing the previous world record of 29 centuries held by Sir Don Bradman since 1948. Gavaskar had previously equaled Bradman's record with a century in the current series against Delhi.

India's foreign office is being reorganized to align with the geopolitical and geographical realities of the country's foreign relations. The work concerning relations with immediate neighbors is being regrouped into three divisions: PAKAF (Pakistan and Afghanistan), Northern Division (Nepal and Bhutan), and BSM (Bangladesh, Sri Lanka, and Maldives). The overall supervision of these divisions will be under the Foreign Secretary, Maharaj Krishna Rasgotra [[2]](https://www.govinfo.gov/content/pkg/CPRT-106SPRT66922/html/CPRT-106SPRT66922.htm).

item.title: Express View on banking sector: In good health
item.description:
#### Summary of the Indian Banking System Reports
The Reserve Bank of India (RBI) has released two reports indicating positive developments in the Indian banking system. The reports highlight the following key points:
**1. Decline in Bad Loans:** - Bad loans of both public and private sector banks have decreased to multi-year lows, with gross non-performing loans falling from 11.6% in March 2018 to 3.2% by September 2023 [[1]](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC7734391/).
**2. Boost in Profitability:** - High interest margins have contributed to the improved profitability of banks.
**3. Strong Capital Position:** - Banks' capital position is reported to be in good shape, with the capital to risk-weighted assets ratio and common equity tier 1 ratio standing at 16.8% and 13.7% respectively in September 2023.
**4. Credit Growth Expansion:** - The healthier balance sheets of banks are expected to support a robust, broad-based expansion in credit growth [[1]](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC7734391/).
**5. Decline in Bad Loans for Large Industries:** - Bad loans of large industries have notably decreased from 22.9% in March 2018 to 4.6% in June 2023.
**6. Future Projections:** - Projections suggest a further decrease in bad loans to 2.1-2.5% by March 2025.
**7. Concerns and Regulatory Measures:** - The RBI has expressed concerns about the surge in unsecured personal loans and has taken steps to manage growth and ensure "loss-absorbing buffers" among lenders. However, the asset quality of these loans has not shown signs of deterioration [[1]](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC7734391/).
**8. Overall Health of the Financial System:** - Despite areas of concern, the reports indicate that the Indian financial system is in good health [[1]](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC7734391/).
In conclusion, the reports released by the RBI demonstrate positive trends in the Indian banking system, including a decline in bad loans, improved profitability, and a strong capital position, while also highlighting areas of concern that require continuous monitoring and regulatory interventions [[1]](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC7734391/).

item.title: Express View on Vijayakanth: The Captain’s exit
item.description:
#### Summary:
Vijayakanth, the actor-turned-politician, passed away at the age of 71. He was the founder of the Desiya Murpokku Dravida Kazhagam (DMDK) political party and was twice elected as an MLA. Vijayakanth had chief ministerial ambitions but was unable to translate his popularity as an actor into a lasting vote bank for his party. Despite initial success in cinema, his political appeal as an alternative to the DMK and AIADMK faded over time. Vijayakanth's journey from a successful actor to a politician was marked by his heroic image and real-life generosity, but his dream of becoming Chief Minister remained unfulfilled [[2]](https://economictimes.indiatimes.com/news/politics-and-nation/vijaykanth-passes-away-a-look-back-at-an-iconic-film-actor-revered-politician/articleshow/106339866.cms).
#### Vijayakanth's Rise in Cinema:
Vijayakanth's success in cinema came after a shaky start, with a string of flops following his debut in 1979's "Inikkum Ilamai." However, his hard work and undeniable charisma helped him rise to stardom. He carved out a niche for himself by playing characters who fought against corruption, terrorists, and feudal landlords. He became known as Puratchi Kalaignar (revolutionary artiste) and Karuppu (dark) MGR. His 100th film, "Captain Prabhakaran," solidified his image as a heroic figure. Vijayakanth's popularity as an actor and his generosity translated into a promising start for his political party, the DMDK.
#### Political Journey and Challenges:
The DMDK initially gained traction as an alternative to the DMK and AIADMK, with an impressive 8% vote share in the 2006 Assembly polls. In 2011, the party emerged as the second-largest party in Tamil Nadu, and Vijayakanth became the Leader of the Opposition. However, the DMDK's political appeal waned over time, and Vijayakanth's dream of becoming Chief Minister remained unfulfilled. The party's fortunes declined, and it became a minor player in Tamil Nadu politics within a decade.
#### Conclusion:
Vijayakanth, known as "Captain," had a successful career in the Tamil film industry before transitioning into politics. Despite his initial popularity and promising start in politics, he was unable to sustain his political appeal and achieve his chief ministerial ambitions. Vijayakanth's journey from a kingmaker to a bit player highlights the challenges of transitioning from the world of cinema to the realm of politics [[2]](https://economictimes.indiatimes.com/news/politics-and-nation/vijaykanth-passes-away-a-look-back-at-an-iconic-film-actor-revered-politician/articleshow/106339866.cms) [[5]](https://indianexpress.com/article/cities/chennai/actor-dmdk-founder-captain-vijayakanth-passes-away-9085773/).

item.title: Civilian deaths in Kashmir: Army cannot afford to lose civilian trust in Jammu region
item.description:
The article discusses the insurgency in Jammu and Kashmir, with a focus on the Rajouri and Poonch districts in the Jammu region. These districts have often been overshadowed by the narrative of the Kashmir Valley but have seen periodic and intriguing developments in the security situation. The region has witnessed a significant number of deaths in 2023, including security personnel and terrorists. The districts have been used as a fallback option for terror groups when their activities are disrupted in the Kashmir Valley. The treacherous terrain of Rajouri and Poonch provides a safe haven for terrorists, allowing them to sustain themselves without seeking mass support. However, the support of the local population has been fraying at the edges, indicating a need for a different approach to gain their trust and cooperation [[1]](https://www.beyondintractability.org/casestudy/navlakha-kashmir).
The article mentions that the Rajouri and Poonch districts were used as access points to the Kashmir Valley during the early years of militancy in the 1990s. However, the Indian Army conducted Operation Sarp Vinash in 2003, which dealt a significant blow to militancy in the region. The operation received support from the majority community of Gujjars and Bakarwals, who actively participated in fighting against militants alongside the Indian Army.
Despite the decline in militancy, the twin districts continue to provide a fertile ground for terrorist operations. The recent ambush claimed by the banned People's Anti-Fascist Front (PAFF) outside the Valley is an attempt to depict the inclusivity of their resistance and expand their influence beyond the Kashmir Valley. The article emphasizes the need for bold and imaginative initiatives and countermeasures that go beyond military actions to address the situation effectively. It also highlights the importance of maintaining the trust and support of the local population.
The article also touches upon the impact of militarization and violence on the lives of people in the region. The Rajouri-Poonch region has been at a disadvantage in terms of development funds, government programs, and infrastructure development compared to the Kashmir Valley. The language of grievance and resistance in the region has a different tone, reflecting a feeble struggle for compensation by unequal citizens. The article concludes by emphasizing the importance of a whole-of-government approach and the need to uphold the faith of the local population.
Overall, the article sheds light on the insurgency dynamics in the Rajouri and Poonch districts of Jammu and Kashmir, highlighting the need for a comprehensive approach to address the security situation and gain the support of the local population [[1]](https://www.beyondintractability.org/casestudy/navlakha-kashmir).

item.title: A look back at AI in 2023: The dangers and the hope
item.description:
#### Summary of "The Impact of Artificial Intelligence in 2023"
The year 2023 saw significant advancements and debates surrounding artificial intelligence (AI) and its impact on social and economic relations. The success of large language models (LLMs) and the potential progress towards artificial general intelligence (AGI) by organizations like OpenAI garnered attention. This led to increased investment and development in AI technologies by major industry players such as Microsoft, Google, and Amazon. However, concerns about the potential dangers of LLMs and publicly deployed AI systems were also raised by industry and state actors, highlighting the need for caution and regulation. The year witnessed both voluntary and legislative attempts to address the safety and regulation of AI, with the US government announcing voluntary rules and the EU passing the AI Act. Despite these efforts, criticisms were raised regarding the gaps in the regulations and the lack of comprehensive industrial policy on AI. The year concluded with a recognition of the challenges in AI policy and the need for greater democratic involvement in shaping AI policy for the future.
The article, written by an assistant professor at the Ashank Desai Centre for Policy Studies at IIT, Bombay, emphasizes the need for greater socialization of AI policy and increased public involvement in shaping the future of AI.
#### Industry Developments and Investments - Microsoft's $10 billion investment in the OpenAI project and the virality of its ChatGPT. - Introduction of Google's chatbot, Bard, and Amazon's Bedrock for large language models. - Efforts by Google and Microsoft to integrate generative models for improving search engines and Windows 11 navigation [[1]](https://www.pewresearch.org/internet/2018/12/10/improvements-ahead-how-humans-and-ai-might-evolve-together-in-the-next-decade/).
#### Concerns and Debates - Verbalization of the dangers of LLMs and publicly deployed AI systems by industry and state actors. - Criticisms of the panic around AI and the industry-centric worldview, leading to the phenomenon of "doomwashing" [[1]](https://www.pewresearch.org/internet/2018/12/10/improvements-ahead-how-humans-and-ai-might-evolve-together-in-the-next-decade/).
#### Regulatory Efforts - US government's announcement of voluntary rules for AI safety and the EU's passing of the AI Act with concrete red lines and prohibitions.
#### Criticisms and Gaps in Regulations - Criticisms of the gaps in the AI Act, such as the exclusion of emotion detection outside workplaces and the lack of regulations on virtual assistants and chatbots [[1]](https://www.pewresearch.org/internet/2018/12/10/improvements-ahead-how-humans-and-ai-might-evolve-together-in-the-next-decade/).
#### Conclusion and Future Outlook - Recognition of the challenges in AI policy and the need for greater democratic involvement in shaping AI policy for the future.
This summary provides an overview of the key developments, concerns, regulatory efforts, and criticisms surrounding the impact of artificial intelligence in 2023, as presented in the article by Anupam Guha, a researcher in Artificial Intelligence at the University of M.

item.title: Why arguments criticising Article 370 verdict don’t hold up
item.description: The article discusses the recent opinions given by Fali Nariman and Justice Madan Lokur on the judgment of the Supreme Court in In Re: Article 370. The Supreme Court upheld the abrogation of Article 370, which was the central government's route to revoke the special status of Jammu and Kashmir. Nariman argues that the judgment is "totally erroneous and bad in law" because Article 370 cannot operate without the existence of a State Legislative Assembly. He suggests that the only valid route to abrogate Article 370 is by employing Article 368 to delete the proviso to Clause (3) of Article 370. Justice Lokur also criticizes the judgment, finding it convoluted and suggesting that the dissolution of the state Legislative Assembly was done in a mala fide manner. However, the Supreme Court found these assertions to be without merit. The article emphasizes the importance of providing reasons and analysis to support opinions and not steering the discourse based on biases.

item.title: Why Indian Express editorial on Kalyan Banerjee mimicry row misses the mark
item.description: The article discusses the recent incident in which Trinamool Congress MP Kalyan Banerjee mimicked the Vice President and Rajya Sabha chairman, Jagdeep Dhankhar, during a parliamentary session. The author argues that humor is subjective and should not be policed. They criticize the ruling party for suddenly showing concern for constitutional offices while disregarding their own treatment of former Vice President Hamid Ansari. item.title: Express View on Bollywood nepo babies: Merit matters
item.description: The article discusses the ongoing debate about nepotism in Bollywood and how the industry itself contributes to the conversation. The release of the film "The Archies," which features three "star kids" in lead roles, has only fueled the allegations that merit holds little value in the industry. This debate initially began in 2017 after an episode of "Koffee with Karan," where Kangana Ranaut accused Karan Johar of being a "flagbearer of nepotism," and gained momentum following the death of Sushant Singh Rajput in 2020. The responses from those accused of nepotism range from indifference to defensiveness, with some claiming that they have the right to cast whoever they want since it's their money. The article argues that the film industry has always been driven by insiders, and the only change is how people discuss those who are born with connections. There is now more scrutiny and questioning of star sons' privileges, including their debuts with A-list directors. As aspirations in India have grown, it has become harder to accept that a few individuals can succeed based on their connections while the majority struggles. The article suggests that the film industry, as a "dream factory," should adapt to the changing dreams of a transforming India.

item.title: Express View: Israel leaders must look beyond militarism
item.description:
#### Summary of the Article: "Israel Gaza: What Gaza's death toll says about the war"
The article discusses the ongoing conflict between Israel and Hamas in Gaza, highlighting the significant death toll and the humanitarian crisis resulting from the conflict. It also delves into the statements and actions of key figures, such as Israel's military chief, Herzi Halevi, and Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, as well as the international response to the situation.
#### Death Toll and Humanitarian Crisis - At least 20,000 Palestinians in Gaza have been reported killed in the war, according to Hamas [[1]](https://www.bbc.com/news/world-middle-east-67764664). - Over 8,000 of the dead are reportedly children [[1]](https://www.bbc.com/news/world-middle-east-67764664). - The UN estimates that at least 1.9 million refugees are coming out of Gaza, indicating the scale of the humanitarian crisis.
#### Statements and Actions of Key Figures - Israel's military chief, Herzi Halevi, stated that the "war will continue for many months" to preserve their achievements, causing grave concern. - Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu wrote in the Wall Street Journal that the Palestinian Authority "funds and glorifies terrorism" and "educates Palestinian children to seek the destruction of Israel". - US President Joe Biden expressed concern over Israel's "indiscriminate bombing" and stated that the Netanyahu government "can't say no" to a Palestinian state.
#### International Response - The UN General Assembly passed a resolution calling for an immediate ceasefire with an overwhelming majority on December 12, with just 10 countries out of 193 voting against it. - French President Emmanuel Macron conveyed to Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu the necessity to distinguish terrorists from the population and achieve an immediate humanitarian truce leading to a ceasefire [[8]](https://www.theguardian.com/world/live/2023/nov/19/israel-hamas-war-live-15-dead-in-central-and-southern-gaza-attacks-say-palestinians).
#### Conclusion The article emphasizes the complexity of the Israel-Palestine issue, entangled in interpretations of history, identity, and geopolitics. It highlights the need for an immediate ceasefire and the difficult process of building peace in the region.
This summary provides an overview of the key points discussed in the article, focusing on the death toll, statements of key figures, and the international response to the conflict.

item.title: Express View: India’s economy, ahead of a new year
item.description:
#### Summary of the Article: The article discusses the recent shocks faced by the global economy, including the Covid-19 pandemic, the Russian invasion of Ukraine, and the Israel-Hamas conflict. These shocks have caused disruptions in economic activities and contributed to a surge in inflation. However, the global macroeconomic scenario has improved, with the world economy growing by 6% in 2021 and 3.5% in 2022. The Indian economy is also faring better, with a growth rate of 7.6% in the second quarter. While there are positive indicators such as falling inflation and increased investments, challenges remain, including job creation and subdued rural demand. The article also highlights upcoming events that will impact the economy, such as the Union budget, the monetary policy committee meeting, and the general elections.
#### Impact of Recent Shocks on the Global Economy: The global economy has faced several shocks in recent years, including the Covid-19 pandemic, the Russian invasion of Ukraine, and the Israel-Hamas conflict. These shocks have caused disruptions in economic activities and contributed to a surge in inflation [[1]](https://www.nytimes.com/2023/11/01/business/economy/israel-gaza-war-global-economy.html). The world economy contracted by 3.1% in 2020 but grew by 6% in 2021 and 3.5% in 2022 The International Monetary Fund (IMF) expects growth to be around 3% this year World consumer prices, which rose from 4.7% in 2021 to 8.7% in 2022, have fallen in large parts since.
#### Indian Economy's Performance: The Indian economy grew at a rate of 7.6% in the second quarter, surpassing expectations Forecasts by the Reserve Bank of India (RBI) indicate that the growth momentum is likely to sustain over the next financial year [[1]](https://www.nytimes.com/2023/11/01/business/economy/israel-gaza-war-global-economy.html). According to Axis Bank research, India's output gap as compared to its pre-pandemic trend is likely to have narrowed to 7% by December 2023 Retail inflation, which had touched 7.44% in July due to higher food prices, has fallen to 5.55% in November The central bank forecasts that inflation is expected to average about 4.35% in the second and third quarters of the next financial year [[1]](https://www.nytimes.com/2023/11/01/business/economy/israel-gaza-war-global-economy.html). The momentum in public sector capital expenditure (capex) has sustained, and the Production-Linked Incentive (PLI) scheme is showing healthy results in some sectors Foreign portfolio investors have also shown increased optimism about India's economic prospects, with investments reaching almost $20 billion for the full year However, challenges such as job creation and subdued rural demand remain There is also little indication of a broad-based pickup in the private investment cycle, despite healthy corporate and bank balance sheets [[1]](https://www.nytimes.com/2023/11/01/business/economy/israel-gaza-war-global-economy.html).
#### Upcoming Events and their Impact: In February, the Union budget will be tabled in Parliament, which will detail the government's expenditure priorities [[2]](https://indianexpress.com/article/opinion/editorials/express-view-indias-economy-ahead-of-a-new-year-9085471/). This will have a bearing on the country's near-term growth prospects [[2]](https://indianexpress.com/article/opinion/editorials/express-view-indias-economy-ahead-of-a-new-year-9085471/). The monetary policy committee of the RBI will hold its first meeting of the calendar year, and there is a possibility that it may provide guidance on the trajectory of interest rates through the year, considering the recent dovish tilt by the US Federal Reserve [[1]](https://www.nytimes.com/2023/11/01/business/economy/israel-gaza-war-global-economy.html). The general elections will follow, and a new government will be sworn in, which will present a full budget detailing its expenditure priorities [[2]](https://indianexpress.com/article/opinion/editorials/express-view-indias-economy-ahead-of-a-new-year-9085471/). These events will have an impact on India's economic prospects [[2]](https://indianexpress.com/article/opinion/editorials/express-view-indias-economy-ahead-of-a-new-year-9085471/).
In conclusion, the global economy has faced several shocks in recent years, but the macroeconomic scenario has improved. The Indian economy is also faring better, with positive growth indicators. However, challenges such as job creation and subdued rural demand remain. The upcoming Union budget, monetary policy committee meeting, and general elections will shape India's near-term growth prospects.

Different mechanisms for foreign listings include separate classes of shares, Global Registered Shares (GRS), dual listed company (DLC) structures, and depository receipts (DRs). Indian companies have primarily relied on American Depository Receipts (ADRs) and Global Depository Receipts (GDRs) in the past. The latest notification has sparked interest in direct listing on foreign exchanges. Regulatory concerns around DRs and ultimate beneficial ownership have led policymakers to explore the possibility of listing shares directly on foreign exchanges without relying on DRs. This could require amending multiple laws and creating interoperability among clearing corporations. Alternatively, Indian companies could issue a special class of shares for listing in specific jurisdictions. Balancing regulatory concerns with the needs of unlisted companies is crucial. A conducive policy on foreign listings could have significant benefits for the Indian economy.
