item.description: The Indian Express recently criticized political parties for making "reckless election promises" and engaging in competitive populism that leads to a "fiscal race to the bottom." The Supreme Court also expressed concerns about the distribution of "irrational freebies" by political parties, as it can strain state finances. While the critique of non-merit giveaways is not necessarily anti-poor, determining what constitutes a public good versus a freebie is a political question. The article explores why political parties succumb to making such promises, highlighting the challenges of mass communication and governance. Parties rely on simple messages that can be easily communicated to the electorate, and direct benefits like cash transfers or smartphones fit this criteria. Additionally, governance for development is complex and often impeded by the political economy, making it easier to prioritize direct benefits. However, excessive reliance on these benefits erodes the party platform and creates a transactional relationship between parties and voters. The article concludes by warning party leaders about the dangers of allowing benefits to supplant other aspects of the party platform.

item.title: On China, BJP and Congress must end blame game
item.description: The author argues that wise leaders and great nations do not remain trapped in the past but find enduring solutions to problems and focus on the future. They criticize the current leaders of India's ruling Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) for being too focused on the past, particularly the 1962 war with China, and blaming former Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru for the conflict. The author suggests that both Nehru and Mao Zedong were to blame for the war, but highlights a practical solution proposed by Chinese counterpart Zhou Enlai that could have prevented the conflict. The author argues that this "package deal" remains the only solution to the India-China boundary dispute. They also criticize the BJP for not fulfilling their promises to "retrieve" Aksai Chin and Pakistan-occupied Kashmir (PoK). The author emphasizes that there is no military solution to the dispute and calls for the conversion of the Line of Actual Control (LAC) into a Line of Assured Control to prevent future conflicts. They urge both the BJP and Congress to craft a bipartisan policy for resolving the boundary dispute and promoting cooperation between India and China.

item.title: November 23, 1983, Forty Years Ago: J&K’s gun problem
item.description: The article discusses various events and statements made by political leaders. Chief Minister Farooq Abdullah has reportedly given clearance to the state police to write about the case of alleged smuggled guns, seeking Interpol's involvement. Haryana, Himachal Pradesh, and Chandigarh observed a bandh in protest against the murder of four people by extremists near Amritsar. The bandh was peaceful as it received support from all communities. Talks were held in Delhi to establish an international study group focused on protecting the sovereignty of small nations, prompted by the US invasion of Grenada. Finance Minister Pranab Mukherjee acknowledged concerns about inflation but reassured that the situation was manageable.

item.title: On ICC ban on transwomen in Women’s World Cup: Catch up and play
Truce in Gaza must be built on
Rahul Gandhi’s ‘panauti’ comment on PM Modi: Stooping low
Why the humanitarian pause in Gaza is not peace
How we are rescuing workers trapped in Uttarkashi tunnel
What male CEOs like Narayana Murthy don’t get about working women and the youth
item.description:
In a recent podcast, Narayana Murthy expressed his support for implementing 70-hour workweeks in India, citing the examples of Germany and Japan after World War II. However, this viewpoint overlooks the gender disparities and disproportionate burden of work that women already face. Women typically take on domestic, caregiving, and professional responsibilities, often earning less and being relegated to secondary income earners at home.
Implementing longer work hours without addressing these disparities would exacerbate challenges faced by women and hinder their progress. The low Labour Force Participation Rate (LFPR) for women, standing at 30%, calls for encouragement rather than further barriers. Additionally, the idea of a 70-hour workweek fails to consider the realities of Indian life, such as commuting time and family commitments, as well as concerns about women's safety.
Advocating for excessive work hours raises concerns about physical and mental health issues, decreased productivity, and burnout. Instead, a balanced work-life approach promotes sustainable career growth and overall well-being, with evidence linking increased happiness to enhanced productivity. Successful organizations are recognizing the importance of flexible work arrangements and result-oriented performance, which allow individuals, especially women, to balance their personal and professional lives effectively.
Data from the International Labour Organisation (ILO) shows that Indian workers already work longer hours compared to many other countries, including Japan. Coupled with meager wages and income disparities, particularly affecting women, it becomes clear that the focus should be on creating more employment opportunities rather than taxing existing workers.
Leaders and organizations should prioritize fostering a culture of productivity, efficiency, and work-life balance instead of endorsing extended work hours. Flexible schedules and responsibilities can lead to greater job satisfaction, reduced attrition rates, increased productivity, and contribute to building a more egalitarian society that benefits women in both their domestic and professional spheres.

item.title: How the armed forces can be prepared for transgender personnel
item.description:
This article discusses the growing acceptance of the transgender community and the need for inclusivity. It highlights that some individuals are born with a mismatch between their chromosomal, physical, hormonal, and emotional genders, emphasizing the importance of recognizing this as natural. The article acknowledges the progress being made in the inclusion of transgender individuals, particularly in the more developed world, and calls for proactive action to help them be integrated into society more quickly.
The challenges faced by transgender persons, including identity crises, discrimination, social stigma, lack of educational opportunities, and unemployment, are mentioned. The article mentions India's efforts to address these issues through legislation, such as the Transgender Persons (Protection of Rights) Act of 2019, and the recent consideration of inclusion in the armed forces.
The armed forces are described as reflecting the characteristics of society and operating under a strong code of discipline. The author suggests that the introduction of transgender personnel should be carefully calibrated to ensure acceptability within the armed forces and society at large. The article stresses the importance of considering competence, educational background, and capabilities when assessing transgender personnel for service.
A social awareness strategy is recommended within the armed forces to promote understanding and acceptance. The author draws parallels with the integration of women in the armed forces' medical services, suggesting that transgender personnel could follow a similar path. It is proposed that initial appointments for transgender individuals should prioritize their dignity and self-respect and gradually increase visibility and responsibility based on abilities and merit.
The article concludes by emphasizing the need for wide discussion and debate within the armed forces before implementing measures for the inclusion of transgender personnel. It also suggests involving the transgender community in the decision-making process to create a transparent and just environment for this marginalized group.

item.title: How former RBI governor S Venkitaramanan helped steer India out of the balance of payment crisis
item.description: The late S Venkitaramanan, former governor of the Reserve Bank of India (RBI), faced a challenging balance of payment problem during his tenure. To bridge the gap, the RBI borrowed around USD 405 million by pledging gold reserves kept outside India. Venkitaramanan tapped into his international connections to raise the necessary foreign exchange. The government also approached the International Monetary Fund (IMF) for assistance, specifically the Compensatory and Contingency Financing Facility (CCFF). Additionally, the rupee was devalued in two steps under the new government in 1991. Venkitaramanan, known for his sharp mind and reformist approach, played a crucial role in making the right decisions at the right time.

item.title: The second quarter report card has signs of optimism
item.description: The article discusses the factors that could impact GDP growth in the second quarter of the financial year. The second quarter is typically stable, but this year may be different due to various reasons. Companies have been optimistic and prepared in advance for increased demand. Bank credit to the retail segment has increased, reflecting households borrowing for consumption. The Cricket World Cup has boosted the services sector, particularly travel and tourism. Indicators such as Index of Industrial Production (IIP) growth, high growth rates in steel and cement, and GST collections suggest a positive trend in GDP growth. Quarterly growth in credit and deposits also indicates impressive growth rates in the financial services industry. Additionally, corporate profits are high, contributing to value-added growth. The RBI projected growth at 6.5%, but it could be slightly lower at 6.2-6.4%. However, nominal GDP growth may be closer to real GDP growth due to negative WPI inflation. The article also highlights potential challenges, including weak rural demand, high inflation impacting consumer spending, and cautious private sector investment. Overall, the second quarter is expected to be a consolidation quarter, setting the base for higher growth next year.

item.title: J&K High Court underlines that criticism of a government can’t be called a terrorist act — and draws a vital red line
item.description:
The Jammu and Kashmir High Court has made an important decision by granting bail to journalist Fahad Shah and dismissing charges against him under the Unlawful Activities (Prevention) Act (UAPA). The court stated that an investigative agency must justify the arrest of an individual under UAPA based on the "clear and present danger" they pose to society. It rejected the argument that criticizing the government is a terrorist act, emphasizing that such arguments contradict freedom of speech and expression.
This is not the first time a court has highlighted the misuse of UAPA. In a case related to the 2020 Delhi riots, the Delhi High Court ruled that ordinary offenses cannot be categorized as terrorist activities. The court cautioned against broad interpretations of terrorism clauses and emphasized that these provisions should be strictly and narrowly construed.
In a separate case involving the denial of license renewal to a Malayalam news channel based on undisclosed national security considerations, the Supreme Court stated that national security claims cannot be baseless and expressed concern about the state using national security as a means to deny citizens their legal rights. The court pointed out the need for the judiciary to question the state's actions and uphold the rule of law.
The court's decisions serve as a check against the overreach of state power and emphasize the importance of justice, democratic accountability, and press freedom. It is now up to the government to heed the court's rulings and respect the crucial distinctions necessary to protect against limitations on freedom.

item.title: November 22, 1983, Forty Years Ago: Brahmachari’s Arrest
item.description: The article mentions that the arrest of Dhirendra Brahmachari is imminent. If he doesn't surrender soon, the police will send a team to apprehend him. The delay in his arrest is due to the ongoing investigation. The Opposition in the Lok Sabha demanded a debate on the raid of Brahmachari's gun factory, but their request was denied. India may seek support from Commonwealth heads of government for nuclear disarmament and a fair international economic order. There are concerns about threats to world peace in various regions, including West Asia and Europe's nuclear theater. In a separate incident, six Sikh youths attacked a State Bank of India branch, injuring a bank guard, but the driver managed to escape despite the gunfire.

item.title: Vir Das’s Emmy opens up space for Indian comedians globally
item.description: Vir Das, a stand-up comedian, spoke about the importance of comedy in a time of sensitive sentiments and online outrage. He recently won the International Emmy Award for Comedy, which could open doors for Indian comedians globally. This achievement is comparable to Priyanka Chopra and Arundhati Roy's success in their respective fields. Das, belonging to the English-speaking class that emerged after liberalization, is familiar with American cultural references and has been politically inclined in his comedy. However, there is concern that aspiring Indian comedians may prioritize global recognition over authenticity and creativity. The comedy scene has become more challenging due to the fear of trolls and legal consequences. It is increasingly difficult to navigate the complexities of belonging to two different Indias.

item.title: RBI, loan scammers and financial literacy: A look at India’s fintech scene
item.description: The article discusses the growth of the digital economy in India and the rise of digital lending, driven by fintech companies. However, it also highlights the presence of fraudulent loan apps that target financially vulnerable individuals. These apps advertise low interest rates but ask for significantly higher repayment amounts. The issue has caught the attention of policymakers, leading to discussions on creating an independent body to verify lending apps and implementing KYC norms. Tech platforms like Google and Apple have taken steps to block fraudulent apps, but fraudsters find ways to circumvent these measures. The article emphasizes the need for increased financial literacy and stronger measures to combat fraudulent activities.

item.title: Heard the one about Vir Das’ Emmy and an India no longer able to laugh at itself?
item.description: Vir Das, an Indian stand-up comedian, recently won an international Emmy for his Netflix comedy special, Landing. This victory is significant for the Indian stand-up scene, showing that there is an audience for their material beyond India. However, Das also faces challenges back home, including show cancellations and legal complaints due to certain groups finding his content offensive. Stand-up comedy in India has faced criticism for not aligning with traditional Indian culture, but the essence of using humor to educate and speak truth to power has always existed in India. Comedians are held to a higher moral standard than politicians and journalists, which is puzzling. Despite the controversies, stand-up comedy continues to gain popularity with sold-out shows and millions of online views.

item.title: C Raja Mohan writes: India should not talk to China — even if Biden talks to Xi
item.description:
The article discusses whether India should reconsider its approach to engaging with China amidst the renewed engagement between China and its Quad partners (Australia, Japan, and the US). While Australia's Prime Minister visited China recently and US President Biden met with Chinese President Xi Jinping, India continues to withhold political and economic dialogue until the military confrontation in Ladakh is satisfactorily resolved. China wants India to put the border dispute aside and resume normal engagement, but India insists on resolving border issues before engaging.
The first argument suggesting a change in India's approach is based on the belief that India should not be the only Quad nation not engaged in dialogue with China. However, India's China policy has independent geopolitical considerations due to its territorial conflicts with Beijing. Renewing political and economic engagement does not solve the border issue, and China is not promising to restore peace if India resumes dialogue. Thus, limiting economic exposure and suspending political dialogue are part of India's strategy to persuade China to restore trust and stabilize the border.
The second argument for rethinking India's China policy is rooted in concerns about Beijing's relations with Washington. The argument suggests that renewed engagement between the US and China could reduce India's strategic importance for the US and weaken Delhi's position vis-à-vis Beijing. However, reopening dialogue without resolving boundary concerns would normalize China's aggression. Summits between leaders rarely result in breakthroughs, and there is no significant shift in the structure of the US-China rivalry. Assessing shifts in great power relations is important, but India should focus on seizing current opportunities with the US and the West to enhance its own power and military deterrence against China.
The article concludes that India should stay the course with its current approach to China. Firm patience gives Delhi a better chance of convincing Beijing to rethink its India policy rather than rushing to alter the terms of engagement.

item.title: A saving on our electricity bills, and the environment
item.description:
The Maharashtra State Electricity Distribution Company (MSEDCL) has announced the installation of smart meters for all consumers to improve billing, collection efficiency, and reduce disconnection costs. Additionally, Energy Efficiency Services Ltd is installing 36 crore smart meters across India to enhance billing and collection efficiency. However, the article highlights that smart meters can also play a crucial role in increasing the renewable energy component in today's energy systems.
Renewable energy sources like solar power have the drawback of limited control over generation, with peak output occurring at specific times. This creates inefficiencies when complementing solar power with controllable coal generation plants. Smart meters can help address this issue by enabling consumers to align their demand with low-cost generation periods, contributing to cost reduction in both consumption and distribution while maximizing renewable energy usage.
In developed countries, real-time pricing passes on the varying cost of electricity generation to consumers. Smart meters facilitate continuous information exchange between consumers and suppliers, allowing consumers to take advantage of low electricity prices during peak renewable generation periods, such as running appliances when solar power is abundant. This practice helps balance supply and demand, reducing costs for consumers and distribution companies while maximizing renewable energy usage.
Smart meters provide valuable data on energy usage patterns, which can help determine demand patterns and optimize tariffs. For example, a study conducted using smart meter data from Mathura and Bareilly showed different consumption patterns between households with air conditioners and those without. Such granular data can aid in better planning and decision-making.
The article emphasizes the importance of utilizing smart meter data and demand-side models to track consumer requirements and predict long-term demand trends in the electricity sector. As India aims to increase its solar capacity to 50% by 2030, understanding consumption patterns becomes crucial for effective integration of renewable sources.
India faces challenges of protecting low-energy-consuming segments of society and reducing high tariffs for industries compared to global standards. Informed tariff setting that aligns demand with supply can facilitate better integration of low-cost renewables. The article suggests fostering a closer partnership between academia and the electricity sector to achieve this goal.
Overall, smart meters have the potential to not only improve billing and collection efficiency but also optimize renewable energy integration, reduce costs, and enhance overall energy planning.

item.title: A cricket outsider writes: It’s not a game – it’s a business that promotes narrow nationalism
item.description: The author, who is not a fan of cricket, reflects on the recent World Cup final between Australia and India. They discuss how being an outsider allows them to critique the commercialization and nationalism surrounding the sport. They highlight the immense wealth earned by cricketers and the growth of the cricket betting market in India. The author also criticizes the way cricket matches, particularly those between India and Pakistan, are turned into a hyper-nationalistic spectacle by the media. They argue that the defeat of India in the final teaches a lesson of humility and the impermanence of victory and defeat. The author calls for a more humble and inclusive approach to the sport, emphasizing international solidarity.

item.title: Not just sanitation, but climate-proof sanitation
item.description:
The recent G20 summit in New Delhi focused on addressing climate change challenges and finding sustainable solutions. However, climate-induced loss and damage are occurring in various parts of the world. India, with its long coastline, is particularly vulnerable to rising sea levels, floods, and droughts. The marginalized communities living in coastal areas face the brunt of these extreme weather events, resulting in thousands of deaths.
Extreme climate events also have a significant impact on water, sanitation, and hygiene (WASH) services. Droughts, floods, and cyclones can damage toilets, water supplies, and sewerage infrastructure, affecting the quality of water supply and leading to sewage spillage. This poses serious health risks, especially for communities in slum settlements.
Water was recently mentioned for the first time in the final declaration of the UN Conference of the Parties (COP27). Building on previous commitments, countries need to make efforts to address the climate impact on WASH at the upcoming COP28 in Dubai.
In India, the responsibility for providing drinking water supply and sanitation services lies with state governments and Urban Local Bodies (ULBs). Despite having policies such as the Swachh Bharat and Jal Jeevan missions, the country struggles to develop climate-resilient WASH infrastructure and sustainable practices.
To understand and improve resilience, reliable data is crucial. The Centre for Advocacy and Research (CFAR), supported by the Water for Women initiative of the Australian government, conducted a risk and vulnerability assessment in the slum areas of Jaipur and Bhubaneswar. The study highlighted the potential climatic risks and their impact on WASH infrastructure in these areas.
Spatial locations of slums play a significant role in designing appropriate local actions for marginalized groups' resilience. For example, settlements near drains and canal roads in Bhubaneswar are exposed to potential flooding during heavy rains.
Several wards in both cities face high vulnerability due to multiple indicators, including illiteracy, lack of access to electricity and mobile phones, and a significant presence of marginalized communities. These factors, combined with the lack of latrine facilities, wastewater treatment, and access to treated drinking water, worsen vulnerabilities and impact overall resilience.
During adverse climate events, tap connections and access to latrine facilities decline, leading to a reliance on government and private tankers and an increase in open defecation. Public/mobile toilets also become submerged and unclean after heavy rains, highlighting the need for climate-resilient WASH infrastructure and community preparedness.
The spread of diseases adds another layer of challenges, with slum residents reporting various health issues. Women and girls face additional hardships related to menstrual hygiene and harassment due to the lack of home toilets.
Despite these challenges, people in slums and wards are adaptive and continuously find ways to address them. They test water quality, repair defunct water sources, and prepare alternative water sources. Governments can support these initiatives by strengthening capacity for safe sanitation, incentivizing the revival of alternative water sources, promoting water storage, and encouraging regular water testing for a resilient and sustainable future.

item.title: Russian Ambassador writes on Ukraine: Whose rules, what order?
item.description: The article discusses the "Euromaidan" protests in Kyiv, Ukraine, which took place 10 years ago. It argues that the protests were orchestrated by Washington and Brussels and describes them as a violent coup d'état. The article also mentions the rise of neo-Nazi elements in Ukraine's leadership and the subsequent terror campaign against politicians, journalists, and activists. It highlights the polarizing effect of Ukraine's chauvinist leadership and the conflict in Crimea. The author suggests that Russia has been the main target of Western interference in Ukraine and criticizes the West's neo-colonial approach. The article concludes by emphasizing the importance of learning from the "Euromaidan" events and rejecting attempts to rewrite history.

item.title: It is high time the colonial institution of the governor is reined in
item.description:
您的免费额度不够使用这个模型啦，请点击右上角登录继续使用！The article discusses the issue of retaining the colonial institution of the governor in India and the problems associated with it. The author highlights Governor R N Ravi's recent actions in Tamil Nadu, where he returned all 10 bills sent to him for assent by the state legislature. The governor has also held up decisions of the state government without any apparent reason.
The article explains that while the governor is supposed to be the president's counterpart at the state level, they often act as agents of the Union government, sent to keep a check on popularly elected state governments. The appointment and removal process for governors is different from that of the president, as governors are appointed solely by the Union government and can be removed at its pleasure. This lack of accountability leads to governors acting in accordance with the Union government's wishes rather than the interests of the state.
The article mentions that these issues were predicted during the debates in the Constituent Assembly. Some members criticized the provisions relating to governors, arguing that centralization of power would cause problems. B.R. Ambedkar justified the existing provisions, but his response was seen as puzzling by some, as he failed to address the possibility of governors acting in favor of the Centre.
The author argues against abolishing the institution of the governor entirely, as it is necessary for the parliamentary democracy system. Instead, they suggest alternatives such as judicial intervention or constitutional reform. Judicial intervention has increased recently, with the court making strong observations to advise governors to carry out their duties properly. However, the author believes it is not ideal for every state to approach the Supreme Court for such matters. The other option proposed is reforming the appointment and removal process of governors, making them accountable to the state legislature through election and impeachment, similar to the president's accountability to the Union Parliament.
In conclusion, the author emphasizes the need to rein in the colonial institution of the governor to strengthen India's democracy and federal structure, either through judicial intervention or constitutional reform.

item.title: In Telangana and Rajasthan, the youth want jobs, not welfare
item.description: The article discusses the issue of youth unemployment and the lack of opportunities in the current assembly elections. It highlights the promises made by political parties in Telangana and Rajasthan to address the problem. The article also mentions the controversies surrounding recruitment exams in Rajasthan and the impact of the Vyapam scam in Madhya Pradesh. The high rates of youth unemployment in the election-bound states are highlighted, along with the challenges faced by young voters. The article emphasizes the need for governments and parties to address these concerns and fulfill their promises.

item.title: ICC World Cup 2023: A live-action show of the magic of Australianism
item.description: The article discusses the enduring success of Australian cricket teams, highlighting their ability to surpass expectations and win championships. Despite not always being the favorites or having the most talented players, they possess a relentless spirit and efficiency that leads to victory. This trend has been evident in recent years, as they have claimed three out of four world titles. The article attributes their success to their ability to overcome flaws and doubts, defeat strong opponents, and thrive in challenging situations. The Australian sporting spirit, shaped by their geographic isolation and resilience, extends beyond cricket to other sports as well. Australia's dominance in cricket has been consistent throughout history, with other teams considering defeating them as a significant achievement. Despite occasional setbacks, Australia always bounces back with their unyielding spirit and determination to succeed. This spirit, known as Australianism, is both a myth and a reality.

item.title: India may have lost the World Cup, but the team of 2023 won’t be forgotten
item.description: The article discusses the Indian cricket team's performance in the ICC Men's Cricket World Cup and compares them to the Brazilian football team in the 1982 FIFA World Cup. They highlight the performances of key players such as Rohit Sharma, Virat Kohli, K L Rahul, Ravindra Jadeja, Shreyas Iyer, Mohammad Shami, and Jasprit Bumrah. The author also mentions the positive influence of coach Rahul Dravid. Despite their defeat in the final, the Indian team is commended for their dominance throughout the tournament. The article reflects on the disappointment felt by Indian fans and the concept of "Australianism" in sports. It concludes by acknowledging the potential future dominance of young players like Shubman Gill, Shreyas Iyer, and Rishabh Pant, while also recognizing the possibility of the current stars nearing the end of their careers. Overall, the article portrays the Indian cricket team as a memorable and beloved group that captured the hearts of fans.

item.title: How Chhath Puja challenges Hindutva and Brahminical dominance
How World Cup ODI 50-over format came about — and its future
item.description: The article discusses the history and evolution of cricket World Cups. It highlights how Australia won their first World Cup in 1987, and then went on to win again in 1999, 2003, 2007, and 2015. India has also had success, winning the World Cup in 1983 and 2011. The article mentions the introduction of one-day cricket, the formation of the World Cup in 1975, and the shift to a 50-overs format in 1987. It also touches on the rise of T20 cricket and its potential impact on the 50-over format. item.title: Why India should invest in mining
item.description: An article in The Washington Post highlighted the potential for Afghanistan to become the "Saudi Arabia of lithium," as the Hindu Kush Mountain range in the Nurestan province is believed to possess a trillion dollars' worth of critical and rare earth minerals. However, China and the Taliban are in a position to benefit from these resources. The article suggests that this development could be significant for India's economic future and its youth. The global transition from oil to electric mobility is driving demand for minerals such as lithium, cobalt, nickel, and rare earths, which are essential for battery technology. The Hindu Kush mountain range could be the new Middle East in terms of mineral resources, and India has the potential to explore and mine these minerals on its side of the range. The article argues that mining and exploration are job-intensive industries and could provide employment opportunities for India's youth, who are currently facing a lack of job opportunities despite headline GDP growth. The government should focus on large-scale exploration for critical minerals and rare earths, supported by robust environmental protection, labor, and land laws. The private sector should be involved in bringing in capital and technology for efficient exploration and mining. The article suggests that India needs to reimagine its economy and focus on job creation rather than GDP growth. The global shift to electric mobility presents a unique economic opportunity for India, where the demand for minerals can generate meaningful jobs and incomes, particularly for underprivileged castes. While ecological concerns are important, the article argues for a delicate balance that prioritizes livelihoods.

item.title: B N Goswamy was the people’s art historian
item.description: Dr. Brijinder Nath Goswamy, a renowned scholar of Indian art history, passed away on November 17. He was known for his expertise and ability to engage with various genres of painting, from classical to folk and traditional to modern. His linguistic range allowed him to match poems from different languages with visual images. His first love was the schools of Pahari art, particularly the Guler family of painters. His monographs on Nainsukh and Manaku are considered landmark works, challenging the notion of anonymous Indian art. He made path-breaking discoveries in his research on Pahari painting, arguing that painting styles were based on family networks, similar to the gharana system in music. Dr. Goswamy curated exhibitions, wrote newspaper columns, and lectured worldwide, sharing his wealth of knowledge with a wide audience. His erudition, articulation, and connoisseurship will be sorely missed. The author, Gulammohammed Sheikh, reminisces about his personal connection with Dr. Goswamy and how his research and publications influenced his appreciation of Indian miniature painting and his own artwork.

item.title: Both BJP and Congress have failed women in Rajasthan
item.description: The article discusses the lack of women's representation in the upcoming assembly elections in Rajasthan, India. It mentions that Shafia Zubair, a 56-year-old MLA, became the first sitting MLA to be dropped by the Congress party. While the Congress denied tickets to some other MLAs, it repeated more than 80% of its sitting MLAs, including older leaders who faced opposition within the party. The article highlights that women in Rajasthan still lag behind men in terms of wielding actual power in politics. The BJP, despite its promise of 33% reservation for women in the Lok Sabha and state assemblies, only fielded 20 women candidates, whereas the Congress fielded 28 women candidates, both far from the 33% representation figure. The article mentions that women public representatives in Rajasthan are often overshadowed by their husbands who hold the real power. The issue of increasing atrocities against women and women-centric schemes are being raised by the opposition BJP and the Congress respectively. However, the article emphasizes that women's rights have been reduced to tokenism in the state, with examples of rape and murder not leading to adequate representation of women in politics. The discrimination extends to other levels as well, with even prominent female politicians like Vasundhara Raje being targeted for personal matters. The article concludes by urging political parties to ensure adequate representation of women in legislature instead of treating it as mere empty words for political leverage.

item.title: India’s drug detox: Digital update, regulator upgrade
item.description:
Recent reports have raised concerns about the regulatory procedures governing India's pharmaceutical industry. The World Health Organization (WHO) has flagged at least seven Indian-made cough syrups as substandard, and the US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) has also raised serious concerns. The government's response to these allegations has been slow, resorting to piecemeal solutions or denying regulatory failure. However, in August, the government directed medicine manufacturers to follow WHO standards and has now set up a team to develop a portal for tracking drug-making processes. This platform will require manufacturers to input details of raw materials and distributors to upload invoices, and will also contain information about spurious and poor-quality drugs. The platform will help tackle the movement of substandard medicines across state borders and track court cases related to the pharma industry.
One of the problems highlighted is the outsourcing of production by pharma majors to small units that often escape regulatory oversight. State regulatory bodies struggle to track down the supply chains of these firms, many of which are fly-by-night operations. The issue of substandard drugs is seen as a more significant problem than adulteration, as it can delay or compromise treatment. A large section of physicians in India do not trust unbranded drugs, and in August, a doctors' protest forced the national medical commission to retract its directive on prescribing generic medicines. Using IT-enabled procedures can improve transparency and coordination between regional regulators, but it should be seen as only the first step towards restoring the credibility of generics.
India has strict laws against spurious drugs, but an effective regulatory mechanism requires a system for monitoring manufacturing and sales units. Most states have not adopted the Mashelkar committee's recommendation of one drug inspector for 50 production units and one inspector for every 200 retail units. Additionally, there is often no clear division between the roles of drug testing and food regulatory agencies in several states. Field officials are burdened with administrative work, which affects their ability to scrutinize the safety and efficacy of medicines. Therefore, the creation of a drug control portal should be accompanied by measures to enhance the capacity of regulatory bodies.

item.title: Cyprus Confidential: Shining a light on tax evasion
item.description: An investigation conducted by the Indian Express and the International Consortium of Investigative Journalists (ICIJ) has shed light on the issue of tax havens. The investigation, called "Cyprus Confidential," reveals how Cyprus has become a preferred destination for the global wealthy seeking a secretive financial hub to hide illicit funds. This is part of a larger pattern, as previous investigations such as the Panama Papers and Paradise Papers have uncovered the use of tax havens to avoid taxes and funnel money away from native countries. The State of Tax Justice 2023 report predicts that countries worldwide may lose $4.8 trillion to tax havens over the next decade. The investigation into Cyprus involved over 270 journalists from 60 media houses across 55 countries and examined millions of documents. It uncovered investments made by prominent Indian businessmen who took advantage of Cyprus' lenient tax rates, exemptions, and beneficial owner secrecy. The investigation also revealed the names of several Indian investors who obtained Cypriot passports through the country's golden passport scheme, granting them both freedom of movement and a shield for their secretive investments. The investigation highlights how Cyprus, as an EU member state, has become a financial hub for Russian oligarchs and has facilitated tax evasion and money laundering. Overall, the findings of the investigation bring attention to the need for government and regulatory agencies to address the challenges posed by tax havens.

item.title: How to solve the problem of stubble burning
item.description:
The article discusses the issue of crop residue burning in India, particularly in the states of Punjab and Haryana. It highlights the factors that led to the increase in stubble burning, including the use of combined harvesters that leave behind stubble, the lack of alternative uses for paddy straw, and the availability of free or subsidized power for groundwater extraction.
The article suggests two solutions to address the problem. Firstly, it proposes rethinking the policy of providing free power and instead offering direct cash/benefit transfers to farmers to compensate for the cost of power. This would make diversification away from paddy cultivation feasible. Secondly, the article suggests creating a market for paddy straw by promoting its value as a resource. Baling machines are already being used in Punjab and Haryana to convert paddy straw into compact bales, which can be used for biofuel production or as fuel in various industries.
The authors emphasize the need to enforce a law against the burning of crop straw once an effective channel for procuring paddy straw is created. They also suggest providing incentives and subsidizing machinery for in-situ use of paddy stubble. The article concludes by stating that with market avenues for crop residue, legal backing, and administrative support, the proposed system can help prevent stubble burning, improve public health, and contribute to the economy.

item.title: November 20, 1982, Forty Years Ago: CM Saikia attacked
item.description:

The article then mentions the Congress party's involvement in defections in Karnataka, Haryana, Nagaland, and Meghalaya. C.M. Stephen, the AICC (I) General Secretary, states that the Congress party has the right to undermine the government in Karnataka by enticing MLAs to join their side. The situation in Haryana is different, but the Congress party now has a majority there. In Nagaland and Meghalaya, the Congress party would not object if the opposition did the same.
Lastly, the United Nations Security Council declares that the Turkish Cypriot declaration of independence in Northern Cyprus is "legally invalid" and demands its withdrawal. A resolution proposed by Britain was adopted, with the council voting 13-1 in favor.

item.title: Message from India’s failure and success at Word Cup: Bowlers win matches
item.description:
The article discusses the importance of bowlers in cricket and highlights their role in determining the outcome of important matches, particularly in World Cup knockouts. The author emphasizes that while batsmen may win individual games, it is the bowlers who ultimately win tournaments. The article provides examples of low-scoring thrillers in past World Cup finals and semi-finals, demonstrating how bowlers dictate the tempo of the game and challenge batsmen to showcase their technical competence.
The author also mentions the current World Cup and how bowling spells have been instrumental in shaping the direction of the knockout games. They cite Mohammed Shami's exceptional performance in the first semi-final, Josh Hazlewood's spell against South Africa, and the impact of the bowlers in the final match between India and Australia. Despite Travis Head's impressive innings, the article argues that it was the bowlers who made the game thrilling by restricting boundaries and executing their plans with mastery in tactics and technique.
The article raises a concern about the tendency to spotlight batsmen over bowlers in cricket, with the media, administrators, and fans giving more attention to batters. It suggests that this bias should be rectified and acknowledges the efforts of the five-pronged bowling attack in making the Indian team successful.
Furthermore, the article discusses the evolution of limited-overs cricket, emphasizing the dominance of batsmen due to factors like shorter boundaries, better equipment, and favorable pitch conditions. The author proposes that achieving a balance between batting and bowling would make the game more enjoyable and calls for more matches similar to the recent semi-final and memorable encounters like the 1999 Edgbaston game.
In conclusion, the article stresses the significant role of bowlers in cricket, particularly in crucial matches and tournaments. It highlights the need to give bowlers equal recognition and advocates for a balanced approach that encompasses both batting and bowling aspects of the game.

item.title: Grand spectacle of cricket World Cup tells us we are one
item.description: The article discusses how major sporting events, such as the World Cup in cricket or football, serve as a unifying force for nations. The author highlights the importance of these events in developing or third world countries, where national achievements can help overcome the humiliation of underachievement. They specifically mention the 1983 World Cup victory for India, which is often remembered as a symbol of confidence and achievement. The article also mentions Argentina's recent World Cup victory, which led to a massive gathering of people in Buenos Aires to celebrate the team's success. item.title: View from Pakistan: Babar Azam’s resignation and a worrying report on children and climate change
item.description:
Babar Azam, the Pakistan cricket team captain, has resigned from his position after three years. Despite his excellent batting skills, there were doubts about his decision-making as captain. Pakistan's World Cup campaign was unsuccessful, with four wins and three losses. Many believe that improving the domestic cricket structure is essential for Pakistan's cricket to bounce back.
In other news, Pakistan has successfully completed the first review of its short-term loan deal with the International Monetary Fund (IMF). The IMF has agreed to release the next installment of $710 million, which is part of the $3 billion standby arrangement with Pakistan. This endorsement positions Pakistan favorably in the eyes of international investors and emphasizes the nation's commitment to fiscal consolidation, energy sector reforms, and a market-determined exchange rate.
However, the IMF has called for transparency and accountability in business deals and urges the establishment of a perfect institutional mechanism for decision-making. There are also concerns about whether Pakistan will rely on the IMF in the future or if there is a plan for self-reliance.
Lahore is facing a severe smog problem, with the city having a high level of pollution. The decline in air quality during the winter is due to various factors such as vehicle and industrial emissions, smoke from brick kilns, burning of crop residue, waste, and dust from construction sites. The government has implemented measures such as shutting down schools, malls, parks, and considering artificial rain to curb air pollution. However, there are concerns about the feasibility and accuracy of these measures, with some believing that the government's response lacks a long-term vision.
UNICEF released a report highlighting the high risk that one billion children, including those in Pakistan and South Asia, face due to the climate crisis. The expansion of urban areas and rise in vertical living have increased water demand, while the government's failure to meet people's needs has allowed private water companies to exploit the country's resources. Disparities in living standards contribute to the deprivation of children, with densely populated low-income areas having limited access to water compared to posh areas with swimming pools.
The report also emphasizes the need to refocus climate strategies and policies on children, as only a small percentage of climate finance is currently dedicated to child-focused activities. It is crucial to secure children's futures and amplify their voices and needs in the climate conversation.

item.title: 2023 World Cup has shown that ODI cricket is not dead yet
item.description: The 2023 World Cup has rejuvenated the One Day cricket format, attracting global attention and showcasing thrilling performances. The tournament aimed to prove the continued significance of the 50-over format amidst the popularity of T20 cricket. While some argue that the format is losing relevance, the World Cup has brought excitement and revived interest. The month-long extravaganza featured exceptional players like Virat Kohli and Jasprit Bumrah, making it a memorable event. Teams like Afghanistan and the Netherlands also provided captivating moments. The semi-final saw Tabriaz Shamsi's celebration after dismissing Glenn Maxwell, symbolizing the passion and joy of the game. The World Cup has injected life into the 50-over format, but its long-term survival is yet to be determined.

item.title: India’s role in the Pacific: How it can prevent a conflict in the region
item.description: Australia has signed a pact with Tuvalu in the Pacific Islands that will provide climate visas to Tuvaluans, highlighting the increasing role of climate change in geopolitics. However, Australia will have to be consulted before Tuvalu approves any security arrangement with an external power. The Pacific has become a theater for geopolitical rivalry, with China signing a security pact with the Solomon Islands and the US gaining access to military facilities in Papua New Guinea. Australia is concerned about the security cooperation between island nations and China. The treaty with Tuvalu gives Australia substantial control over Tuvalu's sovereign affairs, but some Tuvaluans see it as an erosion of sovereignty. India seeks to deter China's aggressive activities in the Indo-Pacific and is engaging with the region through the Forum for India-Pacific Islands Cooperation. The treaty between Australia and Tuvalu sets a precedent for resettlement-for-security arrangements, but it may lead to apprehensions among Australia's close partners and limit strategic alignment. Australia should address concerns regarding security agreements and increase dialogue with its partners. India should expand its engagements in the Pacific to include greater security cooperation and more diplomatic missions.

item.title: How deepfakes shrink online space for women
item.description: The article discusses the rise of deepfake videos and their impact on women. It mentions a recent incident where a popular Indian actress's face was imposed onto another woman's body in a deepfake video. The article highlights the need for advice to be shared with women who become targets of such videos, as this is not a new issue and women have been subjected to digital manipulation in the past. The article references a Washington Post article which reports that a significant number of deepfake images are pornography, with the majority targeting women. The actress involved in the recent deepfake incident expressed gratitude for her support system but acknowledged the difficulties she would have faced if it had happened earlier in her life. The woman whose original video was used for the deepfake video expressed concern for the future of women and girls, stating that even without AI, non-consensual depictions of women have held them back from freely expressing themselves online. The article reflects on personal experiences and the advice given to women to limit their online presence out of fear and anxiety. It asserts that the responsibility should lie with men to be respectful and not violate the privacy of women. The article concludes by emphasizing the importance of holding perpetrators accountable rather than blaming women, as well as the need to discuss the impunity of men using technology to violate women's privacy.

item.title: In Dehradun, a slice of Afghanistan
item.description: Dehradun, a city in India, has a deep-rooted history and ties with Afghanistan. The connection dates back to the 18th century when Ahmad Shah Durrani, the founder of modern Afghanistan, established the Durrani Empire. In the early 1800s, there was a power struggle in Afghanistan, and the British became involved in an attempt to establish a friendly ruler. This led to the Anglo-Afghan War, during which Dost Mohammad Khan, a descendent of Ahmad Shah Durrani, was captured by the British and exiled to Dehradun. He settled there due to its cool climate and abundant prey for hunting. He also introduced Basmati rice to the region. After the war, Dost Mohammad Khan returned to Afghanistan, but his grandson, Yakub Khan, ended up in Dehradun as well. Yakub Khan acquired a property known as Kabul House and spent his summers in Mussoorie. The Afghan royals also frequented the Parade Ground in Dehradun and introduced fruit trees and music to the region. Yakub Khan died in Dehradun in 1924 and was buried in Punjab. After Partition in 1947, many descendants of the Afghan royalty left for Pakistan or Afghanistan.

item.title: Tavleen Singh writes: If Osama can change from being monster to hero, we all need to be worried
item.description: The article discusses how Osama bin Laden's letter justifying the 9/11 attacks has gained popularity among young people on TikTok, particularly those who support Palestine. It highlights the dangerous implications of this support, as it aligns with Hamas and promotes anti-Semitism. The author also connects this global phenomenon to India, where liberal politicians and intellectuals have been vocal in their support for Palestine, leading to the spread of jihadism in Muslim communities. The article emphasizes the need to address this toxic liberalism and the dangerous ideas it promotes. The author concludes by reflecting on the upcoming anniversary of the Mumbai attacks and the religious fanaticism that justifies killing non-believers.

item.title: P Chidambaram writes: Different states, Different strokes
item.description:
The article discusses the ongoing elections in five states of India: Mizoram, Chhattisgarh, Madhya Pradesh, Rajasthan, and Telangana. It highlights the unconventional approach taken by the Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) under the leadership of Narendra Modi. Unlike traditional elections where parties have candidates representing them, Mr. Modi has made himself the candidate of his party in every constituency. The BJP has not projected any individual as the leader or chief ministerial candidate in any state. On the other hand, the Congress and other parties are following conventional rules and have fielded candidates with their own identities.
The BJP's campaign revolves around seeking votes based on the work of the central government, portraying it as a vote of confidence in Mr. Modi. They claim that if the BJP forms the state government, it will be a "double-engine government." However, this argument was rejected in previous state elections. The Congress, BRS, and MNF, on the other hand, are seeking votes based on the record of work of the state governments.
Mr. Modi has also been criticized for releasing a manifesto containing promises similar to what he previously criticized as "freebies." The article questions the sources of funding for the BJP's mega-rallies and raises concerns about unemployment and price rise, which are major issues in the elections. The BJP is considered a weaker contender in these elections, except in three states, where there is no significant third-party challenge. The Congress is seen as a serious contender in all five states, and the author predicts that its performance will surpass that of the BJP.
The article concludes by suggesting that the outcome of these elections may surprise many and raise intriguing questions about the upcoming Lok Sabha elections in 2024. It also criticizes the BJP's claims of economic progress, citing data indicating stagnant incomes and persistent inflation.

item.title: Inside Track by Coomi Kapoor: Nitish Kumar’s many faux pas
item.description: The article discusses various incidents and political developments in different states of India. In Bihar, Chief Minister Nitish Kumar faced embarrassment for his remarks on female impregnation linked to education, which even Prime Minister Modi condemned. Nitish made several other errors recently, including ordering an official to contact the home ministry without realizing he holds that portfolio. Concerned leaders of his party, JD(U), have instructed his staff to keep the media away from him. In Rajasthan, the standoff between Amit Shah and Vasundhara Raje ended after Shah included Raje and her close supporters in the BJP's list of candidates for the state elections. However, Raje may have made a miscalculation by giving Shah details of her confidants, as she could find herself isolated in future government formation. In Madhya Pradesh, Shah is managing the assembly campaign and is hoping to overcome anti-incumbency by changing 25% of the party MLAs. He is also cashing in on the goodwill earned by CM Shivraj Singh Chouhan. Meanwhile, Rahul Narwekar, the speaker of the Maharashtra assembly, is in a position to decide on disqualification petitions against rebel MLAs. The Supreme Court has ordered Narwekar to make a decision by December 31.

item.title: Gyan Panchami, the written word and why Jainism’s knowledge stores are less valued than Buddhism and Hinduism
item.description: The Jains have a long history of valuing the written word and have many manuscript repositories in their temples. However, Western scholars have often overlooked Jainism in favor of Buddhism, seeing it as an insignificant sect. James Tod, George Buhler, and Alexander Cunningham were some of the few Western scholars who took an interest in Jain libraries. In recent years, American scholars Donald Clay Johnson and John E Cort have also brought attention to the Jain manuscript libraries. The Jain community's love for preserving their manuscripts can be seen in their dedication to copying and storing them in gyan bhandars, or "knowledge warehouses." While printed books have replaced handwritten manuscripts for practical purposes, the manuscripts in these libraries often contain valuable works of art and cover a wide range of subjects beyond just religious texts. Gyan Panchami is a day for Jains to celebrate manuscripts and printed books, and it is important to preserve and promote this tradition.

item.title: The embers of Possession – and passion and obsession – never die out
item.description: This article reflects on the author's fascination with the book "Possession" by A.S. Byatt after news of her death. The book, which won the Booker Prize in 1990, tells the story of two modern-day researchers who fall in love while uncovering evidence of a romance between two Victorian writers. The article explores the various meanings of "possession" in the title, including the pursuit of love and the passionate search for knowledge. It emphasizes how Byatt exposes the false dichotomy between academia and passion, portraying even the most jaded researcher as driven by intense passion. The article concludes by highlighting the enduring embers of passion, obsession, and possession found within the book.

item.title: Rashmika Mandanna, deepfakes and us: I find myself constantly questioning the safety of uploading personal information and disclosing my travel location
item.description: The article discusses the concerns surrounding "deepfake" content and its impact on spreading fake news and misinformation. It highlights a recent incident involving an AI-generated video featuring an Indian actor, which has raised questions about the misuse of artificial intelligence. The author reflects on the broader issues of gender-based violence and harassment faced by women on the internet, and how deepfakes add a new level of manipulation to media. The article also mentions the need for discussions on AI to focus on its misuse in privacy invasion and cybersecurity, as well as its positive contributions like early breast cancer detection. The prevalence of deepfake videos, particularly pornographic ones, is highlighted as a concerning statistic that contributes to cyberviolence against women. The article emphasizes the importance of ethical guidelines, privacy protections, and oversight mechanisms to regulate AI. It also calls for responsible media reporting and encourages individuals to be critical thinkers and debunk false information online. Overall, the article underscores the need for vigilance and awareness in the face of the potential erosion of truth and the spread of misinformation in our digital society.

item.title: Alia Bhatt, Deepika Padukone and Sushmita Sen are repeating outfits. You should too
item.description: The article discusses the importance of sustainable fashion and highlights instances where Bollywood celebrities like Sushmita Sen, Alia Bhatt, Janhvi Kapoor, and Deepika Padukone have championed the reuse and recycle narrative. It emphasizes the need to be conscious and mindful of our shopping habits in a world dominated by fast fashion and consumer culture. The article also mentions the alarming amount of textile waste produced in India and encourages a mix-and-match approach to fashion that is both creative and environmentally friendly.

item.title: Reports of Russia’s decline are greatly exaggerated
item.description: The article discusses the ongoing war between Russia and Ukraine and its implications for global power dynamics. It challenges the assumption that Russia is losing the war and argues that Russia may actually be winning. The article highlights the economic and political challenges facing Russia, including sanctions and an exodus of talent, but also notes Russia's resilience and its efforts to reorient its foreign policy towards China, the Middle East, India, and Africa. It suggests that Russia will remain a central player in European security and that its influence will depend on how widely the US defines its global interests. The article concludes by cautioning against underestimating Russia's potential.

item.title: Ram Madhav writes: Why peace in West Asia matters to India
item.description: India considers peace in West Asia to be a priority due to the region's importance as a trade and strategic partner, as well as its energy resources. During a recent dialogue between the defense and foreign ministers of India and the US, both countries expressed concern over the Israel-Hamas conflict and emphasized the need for adherence to international humanitarian law. India has been working to strengthen ties with West Asian countries, including Israel, Palestine, the UAE, and Saudi Arabia. The region is now India's largest trade partner, with a trade volume of $150 billion. India also achieved a diplomatic success when the UAE invited the Indian foreign minister as a guest of honor at the Organisation of Islamic Cooperation summit in 2019. India supports a two-state solution for the Israel-Palestine conflict and views it from the perspective of establishing peace and stability in West Asia.

item.title: B N Goswamy was a storyteller of art
item.description: Professor B.N. Goswamy, despite battling ill health and intense bereavement, wrote a delightful book on cats and their life in poetry and paintings. He also published another book called "A Sacred Journey: The Kedara Kalpa Series of Pahari Paintings." His dedication to his work was evident as he painstakingly traced folios, studied little-known texts, and explored the relationship between painters and their art. With his command of language and literature, he reshaped the understanding of art history. Despite his eyesight being affected, he continued his research and devotion to the artist Nainsukh. Goswamy even ventured into writing a fictional account of a day in the life of the artist, challenging traditional scholarship. His lectures were transformative, revealing the hidden worlds within artworks. Professor Goswamy was revered and admired globally, leaving a significant impact on the art world.

item.title: Who is afraid of air pollution?
item.description: The author discusses the lack of concern for air pollution and its effects on children's health in schools. Despite the harmful effects of pollution, schools continue to hold outdoor events and activities without considering the implications. The author attributes this to the authority structure within schools, where suggestions for change are not welcome. Additionally, parents are often too afraid to voice their concerns due to the fear of repercussions for their child. The author also compares this lack of concern for pollution to the lack of action taken after natural disasters, such as landslides and floods. The overall problem with environmental decay is that it is incremental and subjective, making it difficult to address and prioritize. The author concludes by criticizing the entertainment culture for ignoring or downplaying the issue of air pollution, and emphasizes the need for more awareness and action, particularly from schools and parents.

item.title: Don’t laugh at Balenciaga’s $925 towel skirt
item.description: The article discusses the concept of fashion and how the impracticality and discomfort of clothing often symbolize higher social status and wealth. It mentions historical examples, such as Victorian crinoline skirts and Renaissance-era high-heeled chopines, which conveyed both social position and the ability to afford such extravagant attire. The article then introduces Balenciaga's towel skirt, made of terry cloth and priced at $925, questioning the message it conveys. The internet has responded with ridicule, suggesting that wearing this skirt indicates extreme gullibility. However, the article suggests that this unconventional fashion choice may be in line with the practicality of wearing towels as clothing on a warming planet. Towels offer breathability and can absorb sweat, making them useful in the face of longer and more frequent heat waves. The article concludes by proposing that towels, despite their gentrification by luxury brands, could become a popular choice for casual wear in the era of climate change.

item.title: Governor R N Ravi’s overreach is unabashed and striking
item.description: The article discusses the actions of Governor R N Ravi in Tamil Nadu, which threaten to cause a constitutional crisis. The Supreme Court has previously ruled that governors can only act upon the aid and advice of their ministers, except in exceptional situations. However, Ravi has withheld assent to 11 Bills passed by the state legislature, raising concerns about the politicization of his office. This is not an isolated incident, as there have been other instances of governors appointed by the BJP-led Centre interfering in non-BJP governed states. The Bills stuck in limbo include those related to the appointment of university vice-chancellors, online gambling prohibition, anti-corruption measures, and legislation on the NEET exam. The Assembly plans to pass these Bills again in a special session. Ravi has previously courted controversy by refusing to read parts of the government's speech and making derogatory statements about the ruling party. Even the state BJP unit acknowledges Ravi's overstepping of his role. The article argues for a course correction, with Ravi giving his assent to the Bills and the Centre counseling and restraining him if necessary.

item.title: Both Congress and BJP have made reckless election promises
item.description: The article discusses the promises made by the Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) in their election manifestos for Madhya Pradesh and Rajasthan. The BJP has pledged to procure wheat and paddy at higher prices than the minimum support prices set by the government. They have also promised an annual income support of Rs 12,000 to farmers, which is double the amount provided under the PM Kisan Samman Nidhi scheme. Additionally, the BJP has advertised guarantees such as providing LPG cylinders at a reduced price for poor households. While the BJP's offerings may not be as extensive as those of the Congress, they are still engaging in competitive populism. This is a departure from the Modi government's focus on macroeconomic stability during its first term. The government's welfare schemes previously emphasized targeted cash transfers and essential public provisions, but there has been a shift towards fiscal populism in the second term. The article suggests that reforms and fiscal prudence may face challenges until the next government takes office.

item.title: Why the tribal factor may hurt the BJP in Madhya Pradesh
item.description: The article discusses the importance of tribal votes in the upcoming 2023 assembly election in Madhya Pradesh, India. The Congress and BJP are both actively campaigning to gain the support of the tribal population, which constitutes 21% of the state's population and has 48 reserved seats out of a total of 230. Prime Minister Narendra Modi has reached out to tribals in his rallies, citing the appointment of Droupadi Murmu as the first tribal woman president and announcing a welfare program worth Rs 24,000 crore. The Congress has made promises to empower tribals, including the implementation of the Sixth Schedule, enactment of the PESA Act, and an increase in the rate of tendu patta. The battle for tribal votes between the two parties has been ongoing since the 1990s and has intensified over the years. Various factors have contributed to the erosion of Congress' support among tribals, such as the rise of an educated class seeking political power and increased political consciousness leading to the formation of tribal parties. The BJP has been successful in entering tribal areas with grassroots mobilization efforts. In recent elections, the Congress made inroads among the Bhils and Gonds, while the BJP gained support from other tribal communities. The 2018 election saw a tough fight with tribal factors playing a determining role, resulting in a reversal of seats won by the two parties compared to previous elections. Tribals have expressed unhappiness with the incumbent BJP government, giving the Congress hope of increasing its reserved seat count in the upcoming election. The JAYS, BSP, and GGP are also contesting seats, but it is expected to be a direct fight between Congress and BJP. Despite rising political consciousness among tribals, mainstream parties are likely to continue dominating politics in Madhya Pradesh.

item.title: Every child has the right to a family — Indian law has made this difficult
item.description:
The article focuses on the challenges faced by LGBTQIA+ individuals in India who want to adopt children. The recent marriage equality verdict in India denied LGBTQIA+ individuals the right to marriage, making it difficult for them to adopt. Same-sex couples are not allowed to adopt, and single men cannot adopt female children. The National Commission for Protection of Child Rights claimed, without scientific evidence, that allowing same-sex couples to adopt would endanger the well-being of children. However, the Delhi Commission for Protection of Child Rights and the Indian Psychiatric Association argued that disallowing same-sex couples the right to adopt violates children's rights to a family and the rights of queer individuals to have a family.
The article also highlights that children raised in same-sex families do not experience stigma and discrimination primarily due to their home environment but rather due to the treatment they receive. Evidence from the Netherlands, the first country to legalize same-sex marriages, shows that children raised in same-sex families perform better educationally. The process of adopting in India is long, expensive, and requires immense patience, leading to a higher burden of scrutiny for adoptive parents compared to biological parents.
The article mentions the disparity between the number of parents waiting to adopt and the number of children available for adoption. While there are many orphaned and destitute children in India, the process for declaring a child free for adoption is time-consuming. Efforts need to be made to speed up the process and establish a robust fostering system. The article concludes by emphasizing the right of every child to have a family and the right of every individual, regardless of sexual orientation or gender identity, to parent a child.

item.title: Now and Then: The Beatles came back to say goodbye — and they are going out on top
item.description: The Beatles have made a remarkable comeback with their new single, "Now and Then," after almost 30 years. The track has topped global music charts, breaking the record for the longest gap between their first and last No 1 single, an astonishing 54-year gap. The impact of The Beatles is evident as people around the world have been emotionally moved by their return. The writer personally experienced the profound influence of The Beatles, picking up the guitar because of them and finding their music to be the background soundtrack to their life. The Beatles' significance goes beyond their music; they represent bonds, friendships, love, and hope. They have left an indelible mark on music, popular culture, and fashion, even for new-age listeners who may not be aware of it. "Now and Then" is a tribute to the late John Lennon and also features contributions from surviving members Paul McCartney and Ringo Starr, as well as George Harrison. The song and its accompanying video evoke strong emotions and serve as a farewell message to their fans. It showcases the band's enduring creativity and willingness to experiment with technology. The article views the release of this single as vindication for those who have followed The Beatles and a way for the band to bid farewell while still on top. Ultimately, it highlights the band's timeless legacy and inspires perseverance and belief in the power of persistence.

item.title: In January’s elections, Bangladeshis won’t have any real choices
